Not to mention you are sitting in St. Marks Square Venice. The Venetian in Vegas is beautiful. Great service, great food what more could you ask for....

This was a disappointing restaurant.   While the service was very good, the food left something to be desired.   For all the acclaim Mario Batali racks up I was surprised by how mediocre the food and drinks were.  We ordered a wide variety of appetizers and pizzas to share -- nothing stood out.  I walked away from Otto unimpressed.

I'm a big fan of Mr. Batali's establishments, but was underwhelmed at Otto in the Venetian.  I may have brought my pre-disposition for Babbo in NYC and Boston to Las Vegas.  I had dinner here with 2 co-workers.  We started with wine by the glass $14-$19 was a bit pricy for the wines we had.  Starter was the formaggi plate with 5 cheeses ($23), I would estimate that there was ~8 oz of cheese total split up between the ricotta, robiola, gorgonzola dolce, fontina, and one other I don't recall.  Good, but spendy.  we each picked a pizza and shared.  Good not stellar.  The staff was very attentive and willing to talk about the menu and wines without being overbearing.  A+ for them.

Mario Batali, you definitely know how to cook!  I went here for my niece's bachelorette party this past weekend and it was delicious food.  We all loved the cauliflower pasta the best (Rigatoni).  The Margherita pizza is also a must have.  But the best part of the meal was.....   dessert!!  We ordered 5 desserts to share among 10 girls and each dessert was amazing!  One of my favorites was the dark chocolate.  The service was a bit slow but having 10 gals to chat with, made up for it!  Would love to try the New York Otto someday.

I really liked this place. I dined alone here on October 9th for lunch.  I was seated in the "bar" which was more of a prep area.  The waiter came and brought me my iced tea quickly.  He recommended the spaghetti and meatballs to me, which I ordered. Even though the restaurant was not busy, it did take quite a while for the food to arrive, however it was probably the best spaghetti and meatballs I've ever had.  The sauce was on the spicy side, which I like and the meatballs were pretty much bite size.    I did not order desert and since this was lunch, I cannot speak to the wine menu but would recommend it for lunch if you have the time.

Not impressed.  I only came here because I was sold on the "best carbonara ever" but it was not Sunday, so there was no carbonara.  + convenience of making reservations on Opentable on my phone - being seated in the second to worst place in the restaurant (back corner by a wall) + great service +/- focaccia - appetizer of fried stuff (if I had just gotten the fried risotto balls and paid $9 for 4 balls, I would not have been a happy camper) the butternut squash fries were okay + tri tip was the best dish - mussel/saffron fettuccine was super al dente and really not good (but "cheap" in Vegas pricing) +/- lamb osso buco was okay the lamb sauce was pretty good but the pasta was also al dente, but not undercooked like the mussel pasta dish  I'll only come back from the carbonara, that's it.
Mario the food was awesome and so was your staff. From the eggplant and olives to the prosciutto and mussels everything was great.

To be honest, I expected a little more out of the menu. I found the whole cheese section confusing and I understand food. To someone who does not, they would be lost. Another major issue for me was the menu updates... What's on line doesn't match the menu and there were not even disclaimers, i.e. Seasonal item only! I made my decision to eat there based on two factors. First, j was going to get squash blossoms! Which I know are seasonal. However, their online menu said they had them. Second was the zucchini fritti or simply... fried zucchini! They didn't have that either! The service was just OK. Nothing to jump up and down about. Our waiter brought. Age of breadsticks, asked if we wanted sparkling or flat water then disappeared... I even told him when we mentioned water that we wanted some drinks. Even that was lackluster... no question on what vodka I wanted, no suggestions of wine to anyone else @ the table... nothing. So for service and ease of menu, I have to say, a fail! However... and there is a however!!! The food was great! Pizza was spot on, nice taste, great chew, crispy crust! Just the way it should be. We also had the arancinj and the brussels which I would highly recommend!  Unfortunately, there is good food all over the place. So with a lack of emphasis on the service and lack of attention to details, I can say, I will not be  returning! Still a fan of Mario, but unfortunately there are better places for me to go.

Excellent! After feeling like I was coming up short searching for a reasonably priced, delicious restaurant in Vegas, we decided to just give something a shot. Me and my husband split the bruschetta of the day, large pear salad, and short rib ravioli. All were very flavorful. We weren't stuffed, but that's probably better for us anyway. The flavor combinations were awesome and the view was great as well! No complaints other than the still slightly overpriced menu due to being on the strip. Definitely recommend!

Exploring the Canal Shops I decided to stop here for a glass of wine. This restaurant was the least crowded here and I wanted some quiet time that I could finish my book.   I sat at the bar and it seems I am the only one in attendance at the bar. Such perfection since I have one chapter left. I ordered a glass of white wine and dove back into the pages.  The server was very friendly and let me try the wine to make sure it was something I liked. He even put the fancy bread and oil out with a glass of water too. He continues to check on me asking if all is well. I politely nod and he goes onto his other guests.  The restaurant area is pretty steady with customers. This seems like a true Italian experience, since my server even says thank you and the other pleasantries in the Italian language.    Now finished with my book it does seem time for a little snack. I decided to have on the servers advisement the Abruzzo and Charred Asparagus. The Abruzzo is a thinly sliced pork that is cured and has a little kick of spice. It tasted wonderful. The Charred Asparagus is served chilled with wonderful bits of chopped hazelnuts. The romesco gives the Asparagus sauce a brilliant red color and a zing in every bite.  After finding out this fine establishment is closing its doors in July I am so glad to have dined here while I still can.   The surroundings that are happening out in the plaza of the Grand Canal Shops are so fun and unique. The live performances of jesters and ladies singing is sweet music too all. It's all done in Italian, so beautiful. Here at the bar as a guest you can sit and enjoy the entertainment with a great glass of wine.

Yummy!!  We ate family style, ordering several kinds of meats, cheeses, olives, sausage and pepper pizza, and house made gelattos.  It was all really great.  The wine list is terrific, staff was super informed and helpful. The front patio is fun to people watch and to see the street performers, and listen to the singers. We really enjoyed it and will definitely come back.

I sat right down at the bar. Had a half salad that was perfect size and the corn pizza. The pizza sounds strange but was so great. I would order it again.   If you want something a little quieter, ask to be seated inside. While I was there, there was a show that went on in the plaza that was fun and loud.

Nice atmosphere seated in St. Marks square at the Venetian. They just turned down the lights! Beautiful place to have dinner. My husband and I enjoyed the beets as a starter. We both ordered the veal and ricotta meatballs and roasted carrots. Delicious! We would have given a 5, but they did not have the Tuna which my husband was very interested in having.

Three and a half! Damn Yelp!  This faux outdoor sidewalk café looks swanky and classy from a distance but if you look closer you'll see that the waiters are wearing jeans. Which is cool.  The menu contains all of the usual overpriced, hard-to-pronounce staples of a typical North American Italian restaurant that tries too hard. They have something like two hundred different kinds of wine to choose from, so if you're a wine connoisseur or pretend to be one, you'll be in heaven here.  I ordered the spaghetti & meatballs because it was the only item on the menu that I could articulate with absolute certainty. Despite being the smallest meatballs I've ever seen, the meal was good. I had an overpriced Bloody Cosmopolitan to wash it down and I think I enjoyed that too. (I couldn't pronounce most of the drinks either) It was powdery, but maybe it's supposed to be. I was worried that maybe I ordered a chick drink. My wife didn't say anything though.  The waiter and assistant waiter were both very cool, laidback, and casual as was the lady that showed us to our quiet table at the back.  My only hang-up about this place is their prices. They don't accurately reflect the kind of restaurant that this place actually is. It is a casual atmosphere with casual food (even though the names of the food are a little convoluted) but they charge as if they are some high-class, renowned establishment.

Visited:  On a Thursday at 12:00 PM for a lunch meeting.  Service: 4.0/5 - The waiter was friendly and attentive to our orders and kept our drinks fresh.  Food: 4.5/5 - Started off with the Arancine.  Saffron infused risotto, bolgonese, and the bufala mozzarella made this cheese lover happy.  I went with the Pappardelle at the suggestion of an Italian friend with much knowledge of the food.  I LOVED the thicker pasta and the overall dish was tasty.  The portion of the Papardelle received was significantly less than the dishes my friends had.  The strawberry martini was tasty but also a little light in portion.  Value: 3.0/5 - It can get pricey quickly if you actively order from the great appetizer and dessert selections.  However, I was extremely happy with the ones I sampled this time around.  Ambiance: - Great place to eat, and people watch at St. Mark's square in the Venetian.  Loud enough so others can't hear your conversation, yet quiet enough so you don't have to raise your voice.  Summary - Think of it as a higher end Maggiano's with about the same pricing, with a much better selection of good at a much better quality.  The location of being in St. Marks Square in the Venetian enhances the overall experience in my opinion.  Enjoy..!

We made dinner reservations for a group of us gals on a Friday evening. When we arrived, we had a table ready, but unfortunately it was tucked away in a very tight back corner. We asked for another table, and mentioned we'd be happy to wait for one. The hostesses were really helpful and got us seated about 10 min later.   What I loved about this place, was the location. You felt like you were outdoors in Italy, soaking up the "sunshine/daylight" and listening to live music on the "streets". Very charming touch and part of all the magic in Vegas!   The food though, fell really short of everything I was expecting for Mario Batali. I'm a huge Food Network junkie..and the dishes I've seen him make, looks freaking incredible....just not here. I was torn on trying out the crab ravioli or the pappardelle...they both sounded amazing on the menu...as did the truffle pizza!  After making one of my toughest decisions of the night - Pappardelle it is. First off, it was dark meat chicken. I hate to discriminate here guys, but I'm more of a white meat chicken type of gal here. I looked past it, knowing I was in great hands with Mario's food...but nope. The dish was bland, the chicken was beyond disappointing. One of my girl friends ordered the crab ravioli...I tried a bite and felt like I was eating old seafood. The crab was really dry and had a significant and overpowering fishy taste to it. Definitely not for my palette. So playing with my food, I decided to carb up on my pasta...There was one final pizza slice of truffle pizza at the table of girls, and you can certainly bet I snatched it! That was probably the best dish there for the night. In hindsight, I should have probably ordered the pizza and passed on the pasta dishes. It was perfectly crisp and the truffle flavor was so so sooo good!   Also, note that they will not make substitutions or alterations to items on the menu. I tried that and got rejected real quick. Bummer.   Service was nice, but sort of became hit and miss throughout the night. I felt like there were some moments where our waiter was totally on top of everything and other moments where I wondered if he had flown off to Italy...

Service was...not good!  Very slow, had to keep asking for things and took forever to get them. The salads were very good, but everybody's pasta was not cooked all the way and nobody enjoyed their meals. Bummer

I loved my dinner at Otto! My friend and I were enjoying a girl's weekend in Vegas and stopped into Otto for dinner. We had a great table facing the entertainment in the "square." Our waiter was really friendly and walked us through his recommendations for the menu. We decided to start with the fried ricotta and then share a prosciutto pizza and carbonara pasta.  The fried ricotta was delish - it's basically little cheese balls with a little bit of spice. Yum. The pizza was really good - tons of fresh prosciutto and the crust was done just right. The carbonara pasta was pretty heavy and had an odd but good taste if that makes sense. I think a really stinky cheese was used. I don't know if I would have liked it as just a single entrée because it was so rich but it was a great combo with the pizza. Our waiter recommended a white wine that also complimented the flavors perfectly so overall it was a well put together meal.  I love how Mario Batali's restaurants are casual and yet the food is top notch. I would definitely go back next time I'm in Vegas!
Great food!  Great atmosphere!  Had the pancetta and goat cheese pizza, meatball pizza, and cauliflower appetizer.  Simply delicious!!!

Just say "no"! I am so disappointed in the restaurant and the chef especially. I have life threatening nut and dairy allergies. I simply asked the waiter to sub out a cow milk based cheese for a goat milk based cheese as I am allergic to cows milk. Waiter said he needed to ask the chef. Ummm if I am paying $14 for just tiny plate of argula with a tiny bit of parm cheese, what is the issue. Plus, I also have an allergy to said cheese. Waiter comes back and says " the chef will NOT do it as it compromises the texture of the salad." Wait what?? Seriously are you kidding me? Someone has an ego. It is a plate of greens with cheese, bottom line.  So we order a "caprise" salad. Again, advised of nut and dairy allergy..Guess what it comes out with on it, yes that is correct, nuts. I have been dealing with food allergies for a LONG time and hands down, not only is this establishment down right dangerous for those of us who do have a life threatening allergy, the chef's ego clearly trumps customer safety. So sad.

Every time we stay at the Palazzo we make sure to include Otto. Being perfectly honest the service has  always been somewhat sloppy but the food selection is great - taking specifically about the cheese board and small plates which are always delicious and interesting  We headed there last night and brought friends along with us but were rather embarrassed by the entire experience!  More than 20 minutes after being seated our friend finally got up to find our waiter. We had no food and no drinks only bread as at least that server was attentive - when you bring company and they have to search for service; it's not a great experience   Then the waiter finally shows up to ask what we want to eat - so we just added on drink orders or he would have never taken them. The kids ordered their meal but we ended up having to order again later when it never showed ( and on that note - they may be kids but that does not mean it's okay to compromise the quality - the pizza was over cooked and way too firm; it was rushed like an afterthought and bad )  The cheese board was delicious as always and the squash blossoms were amazing but that is where it ended. The cauliflower was burnt and had we found the waiter we should have probably just sent it back; it was salty , deep brown to black and was mostly left behind! There was also a notable absence of some of their previous lighter dishes like tuna or farro - with a large emphasis on fried and heavier fare - so for me the appeal is gone    I always loved their food and put up with the service - but when both were bad I see no reason to return . There are plenty of other places with good cheese boards and better wine and the service was the worst I have received in Vegas

its basically in the mall's food court. i mean call it like it is... fancy or not. so its inside the grande canal shoppes which is inside the venetian which is one the same huge property as the palazzo and the sands expo center. there is occasionally live opera singers and some little acts that perform in the arena area and there is a mote inside that is more like a little Italian river under a roof. the food court is done really nicely and always looks like its day time due to the painted ceiling. its really not your average mall food court. its way nicer. but apples will always be apples.   dont tell them youre in a hurry. they get that from everyone and they are working as fast as they can. if youre really in that much of a hurry you should have packed a sack lunch.
Food was OK. NOT WORTH THE PRICE. service was good though. Ended with my espresso gelato. Tasted okay.

Definitely not the best Italian I've had, far from it actually. I ordered the sweet potato ravioli with sage sauce and it was decent but it was $24 for 6 small pieces. Outrageous prices. The prices were horrible and the service was even worse. They gave us bread but brought out the olive oil when our dinner was coming out. They said they had no mushrooms or asparagus to put in our pasta which I saw plenty of people that did...not to mention I find it very hard to believe that an Italian restaurant has no vegetables period (as our waiter informed us). It was number 2 on our friend's list of places to eat but I think that list needs to be reevaluated. The location in the Venetian is nice but that is pretty much the best part of the restaurant. The others in our group did like their pizza and I thought it was decent so I threw in an extra star for that.

The location is great but the pizza is horrific. We ordered the Quattro formaggi pizza and it was thin, limp, and thoroughly disgusting. I'd have rather had a frozen Red Baron pizza than this place. And to top it off the service was spotty.

Fan of both celebrities who run this joint.  The problem I had was nothing fully met the expectations of the names.  Went with a group and had a large sampling of the menu.  Some of the pasta was undercooked, sauces were just OK.  Meat and cheese dishes were good, but nothing you couldn't easily surpass at your local Italian market (if you live near one).  And the biggest let down was the pizza.  I've had a lot of similar pizzas: brick oven, flat bread, thin crust, etc.. and this ranks below par.  And for the price it is ridiculous.  It was mediocre at best with a premium price tag.

Ran in for a quick lunch had a break from a show I was attending. Friend wanted pizza so this worked out well. I w looking more for a salad but nothing suited me. Asked the waiter and he rec'd the chicken. They broiled it for me and placed it over a nice piece of grilled eggplant and Roma tomatoes topped off with a ricotta mix. One of the best plates I've had in a while, lunch or dinner. Flavors were an incredible match and finished the plate. Buddies pizza was good as well as also finished every bite. Might have to go back and try their dinner if time permits.

Came here on my first trip to Vegas. Black spaghettini was delicious! Perfectly cooked without huge portions overshadowing taste. The cheese and cured meat selection also made my boyfriend very happy :).

We only ordered one thing which is why I'd normally not review a place unless I try more, but the idea of shelling out more money to risk this quality and quantity of food again is much too painful, and I do feel the need to share our experience. We ordered the Prosciutto Arugula pizza. Had it been decent, we would have ordered the Margherita too. This came with 6 very thin small slices. I like thin crust and the dough was not bad, but it was burned on the bottom. The pizza itself only had 3 toppings: almost no cheese, prosciutto, almost no arugula (literally 3 tiny pieces on the whole pizza) and super tangy tomato sauce. The problem wasn't the lack of variety of toppings. Some of the best tasting pizza I've ever had had few toppings. But there needs to be enough of those very toppings. Anyway, the tomato sauce tasted like it came from a can, but if it was made there which I assume it was, that shows theirs taste even worse than Prego or Ragu, yuck. The little cheese that was there (not even certain there was cheese amongst the strong sour tomato sauce) & meat slid off the entire pizza along with the tomato sauce. I was constantly putting the meat back on. For this dinky little awful tasting "pizza" we paid $20, was it even 12 inches? The bartender was really pushing us to get a 2nd one being it's small. After that experience, no thank you.  The 2nd star is only because the atmosphere there is so nice, it's in the Venitian after all. Violinists were playing behind us, of course little of the good part of the setting had anything to do with the restaurant itself, but rather the lovely Italian inspired hotel. If that pizza is a representation of the quality of their entire menu, then I don't think they deserve that amazing space.

Thursday special, probably the best pasta dish I've ever eaten with seafood.  Perfectly cooked tuna with perfectly cooked pasta! Also had the radish bruschetta special.  Server was Paula, she highly recommended the pasta special dish.  Paula was awesome, very attentive, outstanding service.  WELL DONE, I'll be a customer each visit to Vegas.

Ok,so we stopped in for happy hour. We considered dinner as the menu looked great!  They asked if we wanted water. Never got it! Ordered a drink and got it 20 minutes later. Service was awful! The staff was hanging around 5 fold!  So many choices in Vegas! This was unacceptable. We settled for a weak appetizer at best and abandoned dinner to avoid future neglect!
We love this place. Order the cheese plate, the cherries you get are excellent. Cannot beat the pizza. Made perfect.  Service is spotty so I'm holding off a star

I am not a total foodie I will admit.  But I do enjoy a nice meal.  I appreciate exotic flavors that make my taste buds sing with zesty compositions.  I expected something close to this from Otto, particularly since it is endorsed by a famous chef.  What I got was the worst meal I've eaten in recent memory.  Seriously, there were 4 of us and we all agreed the food was terrible in both presentation and taste.  Here's how bad this was: if they had offered me $100 to finish the food I would have said no.  Well, maybe for $150.  Mario I love ya, but you really need to tweak the food at this place.  DO NOT go here until they address issues with their menu.  Don't believe me- see their barely 3 star reviews on Yelp
Wife was hungry and waitress immediately brought our salad. Made my day! Literally. Schrimp Scampi was good the pizza with meatballs was average

Honestly I had pretty high expectations for this place seeing as I've been to multiple Mario Batali restaurants in NYC. This place was such a disappointment. The waitress was pretty snippy and unhelpful during the meal. The pasta we ordered was all way too salty. I'm a huge pasta fan and I was so sad I couldn't enjoy it. I would not recommend coming here. There are so many other Italian options in the hotel that I imagine are much much better. The only things I enjoyed were the wine, croquettes, prosciutto, gnoccho and some of the salad. While that seems like a lot, I left with a disappointed heart and a stomach half empty.
I loved the outdoor-like square with shows and music. The food and service was excellent!

Staff was very friendly and helpful, great customer service!  I had the truffle pizza with shaved potato on it, and it was delicious!  My husband ordered a different pizza which I remember he loved and it had parsley on it, sorry but that's all I remember.  Otto Enoteca is in the Grand Canal Shoppes in the Venetian Hotel, so the atmosphere is really great for an indoor restaurant.

I love St. Mark's square. I had been to Otto many years ago and remembered they had great cheese so we decided to try it again.  We ordered our wine by the glass. Their sommelier was so nice. I feel bad I forgot his name.  We ordered a 3 cheese board (fontina, gorgonzola and camembert) and the prosciutto to start our meal. Yes they still have very good cheese! It was so fresh and delicious. Prosciutto was sliced so thin you could see through! Yum!  Then I had the pork shoulder plate with a side of their smashed fried potatoes. The other guest had the pappardelle.  Pork shoulder: the meat was super tender and flavorful! I loved it so much and wish the portion was slightly bigger. It came with vegetables in a ginger sauce but I thought the ginger was a bit overwhelming.  Smashed fried potatoes: amazing! Like upgraded french fries. Not greasy at all and very addicting.  Pappardelle: served with chicken ragu and tomato sauce. Very good! Chicken was super tasty, tomato sauce on point and the pasta nicely cooked.

Had dinner at Otto last night because some relatives were in town.  We were 5 adults and 1 child.  Service was very slow and our server was not attentive at all.  My daughter's pizza was brought out within 10 minutes of ordering, which I thought was a good idea to keep her occupied.  However, she completed her whole pizza and our food was still not out (40 mins later) so she had to sit through our whole meal with nothing in front of her. I had the gemelli pasta.  Pasta was way undercooked.  I know what al dente is.  This was undercooked.  The pasta had a horrible, dry texture and the sauce was practically flavorless.  The broccoli rabe was also undercooked in my opinion.  The sausage was nothing special and the whole dish did not come together at all. The bill for the table came to $177 for pasta and pizza.  One pizza came out cold and the pasta's...........well you could get the same at Olive Garden.  Another strike for Vegas strip restaurants.  As a local, I far prefer eating off the strip for better quality at a lower price. #touristtrap

Not worth a trip!  This restaurant definitely caters to tourists that would rather sit in a fake St. Marks square than eat a good pizza. The service was good but the food wasn't worth the price. I had a $25 truffle pizza with only a slight hint of truffle (probably from an oil). It just wasn't worth it!  I expected more from Mario (Eately was much better).

The food was pretty strong. I had a small salad with prosciutto and the sausage and peppers pizza. Food alone would be 4 stars. I get that I am basically eating at a fancy food court; but the service was weak. Lot's of staff running around but, just not getting much done. Slow and lots of apologizing. The hostess spent most of her time taking laps of the restaurant (recon mission) to find out how many seats she had available.

This place was great! My husband was attending a conference at the Sands and we met up here for lunch. We had a unique take on a caprese salad, pasta, and a margarita pizza. Everything was well portioned for lunch to satisfy you, but not have anyone need a nap afterwards. It was all beautifully presented, perfectly cooked, and just plain delicious! We were both very happy with our meal choices and the service was stellar! And to boot, even though the food is top notch, there is no need to dress up! :)  The only reason I'm giving it a 4 vs. a 5 is that is is a bit pricey, but I suppose that's to be expected in Vegas in general. Def recommend it though!

I was working inside the Venetian and went here for dinner with work associates after a long day. They offer gluten free pasta. It was good and convenient. Nothing totally amazing. They have a good and extensive wine list. I also had a bloody mary here a different day and it was delicious (we had a hard time finding bloodys in Vegas).

We were looking for a not-too-expensive-yet-nice place to eat dinner in Las Vegas.  A friend recommended Otto.  It's in the shopping area of the Venetian Hotel.  We split an arrugula and parmesan salad (large, fresh, tasty) and a pancetta and goat cheese pizza (fantastic).  The pizza crust is thin, yet chewy and not brittle.  The bill was about $40, which is a bit more than we would spend at home for salad and gourmet pizza, but was worth the price.

I was impressed with this place. The wait was not very long even though it looked like every table was completely packed.  We decided to hit the bar for a few beers. I forgot what i was drinking but it was a nice big Italian beer for $8...not bad prices for Las Vegas. Just as we took our first sip of beer our table was ready.  Sometimes I think restaurants want you to order a drink at the bar even though your table might be ready...it is a smart business move but as a consumer I find it tacky...oh well!  We were given a great table in the fake outside. These restaurants crack me up with all of the fake elements. I feel like I'm eating on the set of a movie every minute. When are they going to make fake birds come over and try to eat my real bread? At least I hope it's real...the bread I mean!  I made a special request from the waiter. I wanted my pasta cooked in a fresh pot of water with no salt. He said no problem. Some girl in our party...I don't even know who she was but she started giving me a hard time. Telling me the rest of the table was going to have to wait for there food because of me. She also started saying other things but I tuned her out. I didn't know she worked for the restaurant. Oh wait she doesn't! Just completely annoying! I'm still wondering who invited her? I would give her 1 star if I could review her!  Here is the funny part. All of our pasta hit the table and someone at the table said, "can we get grated cheese?". The food runner then said, "I would recommend you try the pasta first because our water we cook the pasta in is really salty and people always complain it is too salty!" I looked right at this girl and said,"Wow that's ironic the food runner would say that!!!". I then looked at the food runner and said,"Load me up on the cheese because I had my pasta cooked in unsalted water!". I then shot a dirty look at this girl sitting at our table. She knew I directed it at her but she had no come back at me! I've never met someone who would attack someone at there own table for a special request!!! I hope she liked her salty pasta dish!  I had the pasta with the shrimp and it was really good. Guess what? It wasn't salty at all. In fact, others at the table commented at how smart I was for requesting fresh unsalted water!  Sometimes it is good to ask and I was so happy with this restaurant honoring my special request.  A slammed restaurant that still cares about making there customer happy.  I love it!!!  We also started with a pizza too and it was really good! I was really surprised at how tasty everything we ordered. I would come back here for dinner and drinks but I will not be dinning with that mean girl ever again. I am so glad I have no idea who she is and hopefully I'll never see her again. You gotta love Vegas!!!

3.5 stars. It was good pasta. All my friends really enjoyed their pasta/pizza. The server was really nice but all entrees are over 20 for not a lot of pasta. It's enough to sort of fill you but I'm used to getting more for take home especially when paying that much. Over all for small portions of semi expensive pasta that was just good not great, I don't think it's worth it

Pizzeria located in the food court of the Venezia Casino.  If you are looking for a quick bite this is a great place to stop. You can buy pizza by the slice and it won't break the bank.  I tried the pepperoni and it was very good. The slice size is generous.

Homemade cured meats, imported cheeses, excellent service. Expected nothing less.   Came in for a latte and ended up letting the waiter choose some items for us. My photos will show:  truffle honey, candied apricots and Marciano cherries as sides with Buffalo mozz, fontina and smoked Gouda. With Prosciutto and salami.   Typing fast because I want to go back for more. Tip here: Let your extremely educated waiter choose for your items for you. Guide them a little but be adventurous. Enjoy this great little escape during gambling or shopping.   Back to the Vegas grind. See you all soon.

We have been enjoying Mario Batali's Carnevino  on our last few visits to Las Vegas, but now we will work his Otto into our regular rotation.  The pepperoni pizza was truly special and the fried gnocchi with prosciutto (not on the menu, but our bartender Reagan recommended it) was one of the best things I have ever eaten.  Didn't even mind sitting in the very busy -and loud - Canal Shoppes.   Can't wait to return!!!

I will fully acknowledge that being from California (born in So Cal, now living in Nor Cal), I am a food critic without a doubt.  I also understand that Vegas restaurants that are play offs of their main establishments are meant to cater to a broader variety of people that often come at the sacrifice of quality and variety.  In any case, however, what I'm trying to get at is, it'll be good, but there aren't too many places that I seem think are great.  Such is the case with Otto Enoteca.  Greg and I stopped off here after wandering around the Venetian and trying to find a place that was moderately priced for a Linner (Lunch + Dinner).  Greg had just visited Mario Batali's place in LA, so naturally he thought to try here just out of curiosity.  We both decided against pizza since that usually gets taken care of past midnight in Vegas, so we went with two pasta dishes: Bucatini all'Amatriciana and Gemelli.  Leading up to this, we ordered two drinks, a Bellini and a beer while waiting for our food.  Our waitress was nice and very courteous, but what I didn't understand was the table bread situation.  After we requested the bread, it came out in a basket...and that was it.  No butter, no olive oil, no salt and pepper on the table, just bread.  Um, ok?  We were starved, but they certainly didn't put much effort into presentation.  The bread itself was delicious, but it probably would have been better with something else.  Anyway, the mains came out, and the waitress had warned us that they serve the pasta al dente.  No kidding, as it would seem.  I typically don't like al dente but was willing to try it.  My dish, the Bucatini, had great flavor to it with a spicy tomato sauce, onions, and some cured  pork.  My only issue was, much like the bread, it was literally just pasta on a plate.  No additional decorations, no detail to presentation, just pasta on a plate.  The plate itself wasn't that big, but I wasn't going to complain about the portion.  Anyway, Greg's plate was also good, and he was convinced that his plate was better than mine.  I had one bite (the maximum bites I was allocated) and it was tasty.  Anyway, after the meal was over, we sat around and people watched which I would say is valuable since there's a million things going on in that little plaza.  Ultimately, I'd say this place is a little pricey considering the fact that a) it was just pasta, b) absolutely nothing special done for the dishes, and c) I think like most places in Vegas, the restaurant can hike the prices up since people like myself will pay for it.  I might come back here next time if I feel like pasta, but for $35/person, I'll see if I can go somewhere else.

We sat down in this restaurant because of the nice view to the Venetian plaza. The food is really mediocre, though. The service was okay. There are way better options if you're looking for Italian food in Vegas.

Otto is my favorite place for pizza in Vegas.  Served traditional style,  the Margherita is highly recommended for a healthy choice.  Nice relaxed ambience at the classy Venetian mall,  you may be lucky and catch a live puppet show during dinner in the courtyard seating area.
Quality meal this week. Sampled several items from the menu. The star was the melon salad. Great atmosphere and people watching from the restaurant.

My experience here was only ok.  I was really looking forward to this being an amazing restaurant, but sadly it wasn't.  Our waiter was nice, but forgot all of the specials that I heard being described to other tables around us.    I was really excited about the pasta I ordered, but was really disappointed by how tiny the portions were.  My pasta was literally less than 10 bites of food, which was sad, especially for $25.  My friends ordered pizza, which was much larger and more filling, so I regretted not ordering that.  We shared 2 scoops of gelato for dessert, and that was the highlight of the meal for sure.  Salted caramel + chocolate malt was a great combination.  Overall I'd say it was ok, but if I go back to Vegas I'll likely go elsewhere for Italian food.

Loved this place! The food was light and fresh, and the service was quick. I've been here a few times, and I've enjoyed the pizza, the salad, and the pasta. This is a great place for a reasonably priced and delicious meal in Vegas.   Go for the Margherita D.O.C. Pizza and  the Rigatoni with Ragu Napolitana!  The location is fun, too, with tons of people watching, and quasi-al-fresco dining with no threat of rain or cold. Service has always been friendly and efficient. Definitely a low-stress go-to option in the Venetian.

During a recent trip to vegas, my mother and I ate at this restaurant.  It was good, but nothing spectacular.  The highlight of the meal were the two salads.  I had the octopus salad, while my mother had the panzanella.  The octopus was tender and the potatoes and celery made the perfect, crisp foil against the fish.  My mother's panzanella was light and refreshing, although a touch too sweet for my tastes.  For an entree, I had the braised pork shoulder, which the waiter said was a house specialty.  The meat was a little dry and stringy and the sauce was cloyingly sweet.  My mother had the pasta ala norma.  The sauce was good, but the pasta was very undercooked and I am not talking about al dente.  It was almost crunchy.

Nice Italian fare at high prices...Its an Ok place and has a decent wine list but it is a pricy spot for what you get, but it is location etc.  Salads were great and the appetizer selection was a shared pizza.  Entrees were the pastas and we shared but there was really nothing memorable.  A nice spot and I would go back but nothing out of the ordinary.  Great service

Ate here recently for lunch. There are daily specials for bruschetta, pizza, and pasta on the menu which are worth looking at. We had the Monday special pizza which was a caramelized balsamic onion and ricotta -- it was so good! I will say that the prices were a little high, although that is probably to be expected given the location in St Marks Square on the Grand Canal. We came out at about $60 for three people with no drinks, dessert, etc.

Came in for dinner and has some delicious pasta.  Ordered linguine and spaghetti and both were delicious. Ingredients were fresh and sauces were simple but full of flavor.   Also tried the salad with pear and walnut. That was good but not anything special. Felt the same about the bread.  The service was very good, though they do pack you in very tight. It was very uncomfortable seating. I had to keep my chair in one spot exactly to not bump into the person behind me.

We enjoyed a lovely meal watching the tourists wander through the Canal Shops.  We started with a cheese plate left to the server's discretion and weren't disappointed.  Our server brought a selection of 7 cheeses plus apricots, honey, and cherries on the side.  Although we missed having some bread or crackers to use with the softer cheeses, it was a great experience to try some new flavors.  We both enjoyed pizzas that were very tasty (the tomato sauce was incredibly creamy), followed by delicious double cappuccinos.    Although the environment was a bit noisy from the crowds, the people-watching was incredible, the service was spot-on, and the food was a great choice for lunch.

My experience was amazing loved my Peroni beer , loved my Baby lettuce salad ,fried ricotta and had the procuitto pizza added chilies wow ! Will come back for sure for steak I heard it's the best NY strip on the Strip.

I must admit my Bf and I were very hesitant to come to this place after reading a few yelp reviews. However, my Bf had a change of heart last minute and we wanted to try it out for ourselves and I am sure glad we did. We ordered their Insalata di Mare which was divine. I cannot express myself enough if you are a seafood lover how tasty this salad is and is a must try. Being a cheese fanatic since birth I ordered their Quattro Formaggi Pizza. I really must rave about this pizza for cheese lovers. The presentation of this pizza was very clever and it was delicious. I don't want to ruin the surprise for first timers but you won't be disappointed.   We arrived during happy hour so we took advantage of their beer and drink specials. Their house made Gelato is also a must try. If you are looking for a yummy spot for Pizza, Drinks and a wonderful ambiance at the Venetian. Look no further. Come to Otto.

We dined here a few days ago before heading out for the night, and I was impressed with many of the offerings.   We began with a bellini and selections from the cheese and salami options. The Camembert, Gorgonzola, and prosciutto were divine, and the one of the accompaniments - honey with truffle shavings - was the perfect pairing. I also enjoyed dipping the bread they provided in the olive oil and balsamic vinegar, however, the bread was nothing special; neither were the other cheese accompaniments.   My dining companion had the salami pizza, which was nicely crisp and generously topped with good salami, but it did not "wow" me. I had the ravioli, which was filled with delicate and succulent bits of short rib - delicious!  We were going to have dessert, however, our server took too long. In fact, that was one of my only gripes with Otto: while our server was very knowledgeable, I believe the place was understaffed, as he was running around to other tables in different sections and even working behind the bar area; therefore at times he would disappear for long periods of time or seemed rushed when answering questions or taking our orders.

Another Mario Batali restaurant in the Venetian.  I believe he has four restaurants here.  We came here during lunch and ordered two pizzas.  It's a little pricey compared to Grimaldi's ($42 for two personal size pizza's compared to $22 for a large pie at Grimaldi's) but I was surprised how much I liked it.  The crust was nice and crispy.  I liked the prosciutto arugula pizza.  The Margherita pizza was good but at $21 they could of added more buffalo mozzarella cheese.    There are a lot of pizza places at the Venetian, so pick the one that has the best value for you.  You can go casual or upscale like Otto.
Fav lunch place! love the ambience & the pizza! ordered thin crust vegetarian pizza with tomatoes, mushrooms, olives 3 days in a row.

don't get me wrong, i liked this place just fine. i would give 3.5 stars if possible.  I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THE CAPRESE. it's a different take than other caprese salads i've had in the past; this one is mini heirloom tomatoes (cherry tomato size) with pesto on top and THE BEST MOZARELLA I'VE HAD IN MY LIFE. it was so creamy, so light and fluffy with a texture that i've never encountered before. sort of...bouncy and squishy like mochi almost. it was so good!  other things we ordered: anchovy pizza and sausage pizza: both yum. if you like the thin pizza style, you'll like these. very hearty!  carbonara pasta: ? was this really a carbonara? it wasn't very creamy and the black pepper killed any other subtle tastes there may have been. i'm used to japanese style carbonara so maybe it's different? but i didn't taste that creamy, egg-y flavor that is absolutely necessary in a carbonara.  minus one star for being overpriced, and minus another half for just so-so pizza and pasta. minus another half for their bread selection not being so exciting. i love italian places with delicious, soft warm breads to eat before your meal.  dat mozarella doe.

My wife and I, traveling looking for one place to eat decided to eat here as she remembered reading about it somewhere before our trip. The service was very good and we were seated quickly with prompt service However, I would attribute that to perhaps that we were eating dinner early for Vegas standards and was not very full.  Although I have never been to Italy, my wife has and assured me the food was very authentic. She had the pancetta and goat cheese pizza and I had the Napoliante or pasta with veal in sauce. Both were excellent. I also recognized that Mario Batteli is one of the owners, which is not a reason to rate a food both very interesting.
Pasta was terrible, pizza was horrible. This is a place that uses tourists ignorance and charges an arm and leg.  Stay away.

I came here for happy hour with a couple girl friends and we all got the little happy hour selections but one of my friends and I both received olives even though we had ordered something else. Also the fried zucchini had NO seasoning on it and no sauce, so it wasn't very good. I came for lunch and I have to say the lack of seasoning really ruined a nice light lunch (caprese salad). Where's the salt?
The goat cheese and pancetta pizza was a perfect pair.   I wish I could eat it once a week for the rest of my life. The deep fried prosciutto was a unique appetizer with great texture.

Nice casual spot.    Carbonara pizza was good, margherita was forgettable.    Pastas were not bad, not amazing.  The pork shoulder was a real winner.  Crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside.  That dish is highly recommended.    Prices are reasonable, especially for Vegas.

This is like having lunch outside in Italy.  Probably because you are in the Venetian and they have various minstrels roaming about.  The hottie made reservations for thus place because she wanted to try the appetizers.  We started with the frittes and it did not disappoint.  My favorite was the arancini.  Kind of a cheesy saffron rice ball fried up.  The hottie loved the cauliflower fritters.  There was also a wild mushroom bruschetta that was excellent.  For entree I got together pork shoulder.  Kinda like pulled pork but not yet pulled apart.  The hottie got the veal and ricotta meatballs.  Good but be warned this is meatball only with no pasta.  The waiters disappeared too often but all the food was good.  A perfect lunch spot.
Decent place, staff innate native beautiful views outside food middle of the road price ok..honestly nothing I'd seek out or be averted to.

Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich have their mitts all over the Venetian and Palazzo with a handful of restaurants. This one is at the mid-level price range so if you want to scratch that Italian food itch, this is a solid moderately priced option.   Rather than being set in a dark restaurant the 'outdoor seating' vibe makes you feel like you're in an outdoor Italian sidewalk cafe. That makes it casual and relaxed, including occasional performances on the town square under the faux Venetian 'sky'.  The menu offers a decent range of unpretentious simple Italian dishes and a robust wine list. The prices are pretty reasonable for the most part for the quality of food. I say relatively because much of Vegas fine dining is overpriced, including Mario Batali's restaurants. It's not the food prices that are the problem, it's the drinks and wine that are jacked up to the top end of the scale.   Overall, you can count on a delicious meal here with decent service featuring all the things we love about true Italian fare.   That's why we come every time in Vegas. It usually works out to $50-$70 a person all-in.   Cheers!

The food was good. Authentic; I'll give it that. The service was okay. Overly attentive at times followed by no attention at all for 15 to 20 minutes at a time. Prices were good considering that you're in the Venetian at a celebrity chef's venue. Legitimate wine selection. In short, your stomach will likely be satisfied and your wallet will likely not be empty.   However, I cannot overlook a very racist remark Mario Batali made not long ago. It will not stand I'm sure folks will chime in with contrary opinions. Feel free but just like Mr. Chik-Fil-A who chose to use his position and power to spew messages of hate, Mr. Batali has to face the consequences of revealing private opinion in a public setting. In this case that consequence is not terribly significant; I will simply never be a patron. Had I not been invited by my boss I would never have stepped foot in any of his establishments.

Mario is my favorite chef. Period.  This location, however, does not meet the standards of any of his NYC restaurants. The service is ok, but really lacks the polish and finesse you'd expect at a B&B restaurant. Pizzas are great, as always. Cheeses are great too. I go here any time I'm at the Palazzo for a glass of wine and cheese. Save your "meals" for elsewhere. Carnevino, for example.

I like the one in NYC a little better, but this one is also very good! I love the simple Italian food that they do and the ambiance is so different from the one in NYC.   The restaurant has an "outside" sitting area which feels like a balcony or terrace and gives you the feeling that you are sitting outside in a piazza somewhere in Rome. The area is lively and filled with activity with people performing in the area just right outside the restaurant. Absolutely loved the atmosphere here!  The food is delicious with the pastas being my favorite as they are simple yet full of flavor. My mom had the truffle pizza and she loved the thin crispy crust! Service was wonderful with our waiter attentive and ready to get us whatever we needed.  All in all a great experience, if you're looking for a nice lively lunch spot or just want a nice relaxing meal from the hectic pace of Vegas then come to Otto :) (and don't forget to check the one out in NYC)

This place kicks so much ass. Probably my best meal in Vegas and I'm not even that into Italian food. I tend to avoid Italian places when outside of the northeast due to them not usually being as good as the food in places like Federal Hill in Providence and usually being twice the price. Otto proved me wrong.  I started with a selection of two cheeses, taleggio and fontina. My girlfriend ordered the roasted tomato and cucumber panzanella.  I think about that cheese like fourteen year old girls think about Justin Beiber. It was one of the best things I have ever had. I enjoyed it with the table bread and it was served with some type of blueberry, another type of preserved apricots and some incredibly good, fancy honey which appeared to have truffle in it. I'm not 100% sure what was in the accompaniments but it was all fantastic. Creamy cheese with the honey on crusty bread mmmmmhhmmm. I knew right when I was eating it that I would miss that plate until the next time I visit. Cant stress enough how much I liked this.  My girlfriend said the same about the panzanella. I took a bite and agreed. It wasnt something either of us would normally order but it all came together so perfectly. I'm not one to take a bite of plain tomato but I would eat mountains of this.   My entree was the Rigatoni with Ragu Napolitana. Big perfectly al dente rigatoni noodles with a veal ragu that was pretty much just stunning. It got better with every bite. At first I wasnt that impressed. Then I kept tasting it and noticed how perfectly and simply flavored everything was. Just another incredible dish..  My girlfriend had the Bucatini. I'll just say she thought everything of her pasta that I did mine.   The service was fine. Attentive but not overbearing. nothing incredible but certainly passable. No complaints.  I never really liked Batali much on tv but after eating his food I feel a little differently.

after a week in Vegas, this is the rare place where amazing European Italian food is served. felt close to home and finally like I was eating normal food again.  for starter, try the persutto and cheese. for main dish, the persutto pizza or.the steak tagliata. The steak.tagliata salad had to much Parmesano cheese,  my only complaint. amazing place to eat which is a must try while in vegas. staff is super nice and fast. FYI for my European people this place offer REAL ILLY Coffee, only place in vegas.

This restaurant is in the strip of the hotel shopping area. It was indoors but I felt like I was outside. The food was great. The pizza was the best I have had in recent memory. And the pasta was amazing! The price was not very expensive! I want to try all the pizzas!

I had been here before the name change.   I like it better now.   We had a great waitress (Susan).  She was attentive, helpful, and had great insight into Vegas history and sights.    We split the verdure grande platter.  Everything on it was excellent, except the beets.  (They were probably fine, but I don't care for them.)  I loved the garbanzos with tuna, the farro, the lentils and the squash.  The broccoli with chile was fine, as was the eggplant caponata.  I wish I had asked for the marinated olives.    Jeff and I split a pizza that had goat cheese, prosciutto and a light tomato sauce.  The dough was thin and crisp.  The saltiness of the prosciutto was ameliorated by the sliced green onions and the cheese.  A bit salty, but a delicious bite.    We were lucky that the olive oil gelato was available.  Each bite was excellent.  There were buttery, flowery notes, but not the gross mouth feel nor overly sweet aftertaste of some ice creams.  We had it with the pear and chocolate gelatos.    Excellent service.  Excellent food.  Nice location.  (A little pricey.)
A little expensive.  $42.00 for a 10" with two sodas.  The ingredients were high end delicious.  Awesome pizza.  The service was impressive.

The food was pretty good but the server was so bad it ruined our experience.  Everything you could imagine a server could do wrong happened...Better service would have bumped this review to a 3.5 or 4 star spot.

I had the Caprese  salad and it was delicious. It's unique being that it's not your typical Caprese. I also had it in November and the bartender told me that they use a different tomato style in the summer.
Been here multiple times... I'm a big Fan of Batali restaurants .. Luv them all! From Babbo in New York to Osteria Mozza in LA, B&B in Vegas .....Enjoyable always! And worth the money!

After the enthusiastic recommendation of some foodie friends, we decided to try Otto Enoteca for lunch on a Sunday afternoon.  Although the restaurant seemed full, we were promptly seated at a table that afforded a view of the square (i.e. I watched a "statue" throughout our entire meal).  Our waiter was enthusiastic and I must note, pronounced the Italian perfectly (although he clearly wasn't Italian).  He guided us through the menu and since we weren't that hungry (and had dinner reservations for Bouchon), we decided on an appetizer and a pasta dish to share.  We got the gnocco frito, and per the waiter's suggestion, had prosciutto wrapped around it.  HEAVENLY!  I've never had anything like it:  it was almost like a savory funnel cake with salty prosciutto and finely grated fresh parmesan.  Omg, yum yum yum.  The portion was huge too - definitely a share-able appetizer!  We then got the spaghetti and meatballs, which is my favorite dish and I'm always on the search for the best meatball ever.  Were these it?  No, but I loved the spicy-ness of the dish and the freshness of the basil really paired well with the pasta.  One of my favorite things about Otto Enoteca was the wine.  Otto has an enomatic wine dispenser, which permits you to get small to large glasses of wine, based on what you like.  This means that your gamble on wine is actually quite diminished; something interesting for Vegas where gambling is so prevalent!  I took advantage of and got a small glass of the Brunello.  The bottle retailed for $220, but my small glass was just $17.50.  A coup, if you ask me, to sample a super rare vintage of one of my favorite wines.  Yay.  Hubby went the amari route and the manager gave us a very personalized walk through of the numerous selections, pointing out the specific ones beloved by Mario.  So special!  The manager seriously spent about 20 minutes just with us walking through all the various types, before we settled on 4 different ones to taste and savor.  And yes, artichoke liquer is actually tasty!  All in all, impeccable service, unique italian eats, and a great people-watching spot make this one a fun afternoon spot.  I would definitely go again and try the pizza, which looked amazing!    But note:  Is it the best Italian you will ever have?  Nah, so I'm not sure I'd recommend this as a prime time dinner spot (especially with the price tag), but I did really enjoy it!  One weird thing worth noting:  we ordered soda water, but it wasn't until the end of the meal that I realized it was being poured from a fancy bottle instead of simply served from behind the bar.  And then the bill came:  $7/bottle.  Oooooooops.

Otto is one of my favourites in Vegas, and the prices cant be beat. In typical Las Vegas fashion, you can spend as much as you want here. But if you are tight on money, 2 can eat here for under $25 very easily.  Booked through Open Table, and was seated right away in a small room in the back. Was the first time i was back here, usually sat on the plaza. I love sitting out there, especially when the opera singers and violinists are performing. The Venetian is so pretty, I love walking through it along the canals with gondolas.   I have been to both locations of Otto, Las Vegas, and New York City. The menus are pretty similar, but i find the wine list is better in NYC. I am a fan of this really obscure Italian wine, and the NYC location has it, LV doesn't. But don't let my snobbery cloud a really good wine list in LV.  You can order 2 different sizes of salads, which i like. Had the arugula and parmesan which was very tasty!  The pizza's here are fantastic. Had the house-made sausage and peppers pizza which was cooked perfectly. The sausage has a bit of heat to it, and the thin crust is awesomely cooked.  Otto is a great way in Vegas (and NYC) for great food and great prices!

Good spot for Italian dining.  I feel the menu is a bit limited in terms of pasta dishes.   I was looking for shrimp scampi for the longest time and settled for the linguine.  The dish was absolutely amazing!   I could have definitely has a whole other serving of it as it was that good.  The pasta itself was the best part as it was cooked perfectly and had this amazing consistency to it.  The sauce was absolutely divine and made me want to fill a thermos with it and drink it.   I definitely recommend this spot.   While the dishes seem basic they are very well made.  It really makes you appreciate the quality in a simple well-made dish.     Fancy decor.  If you eat in the venue it is a nicely decorated spot with dozens of wine bottles adorning the walls.   "Outside" seating has you in a fenced Ibarra of the Grand Canale Shoppes under the artificial sky ceiling that adds the perfect touch to the meal

Amazing food. Had this when I came back in September to Vegas and had the pepperoni pizza and it was so amazing that I wanted to get it again but unfortunately they were out of pepperoni. The waiter suggested the prosciutto and arugula pizza and it was okay, but was definitely looking forward to the pepperoni.  We also ordered the margarita pizza (which we had before as well) and it was good as always. We also tried the snap peas which were very good and they allowed us to customize the spice level which was nice. Always have great food while coming, just wished I couldve had the pepperoni pizza.

Mario Batali is everywhere. Thankfully I'm a fan.  This is my second visit here, and an updated review is in order. I now give it a solid four stars.  The location and atmosphere are festive. Even though this is "make believe", you could drink yourself into believing you are among the great cathedrals in Venice.  Our party really enjoyed the spaghetti and meatballs, shrimp linguini, and steak tagliata. The meatballs are made using beef brisket. The meat is seasoned well, and had a unique dense texture. The spaghetti and linguini pastas were outstanding. The pasta was cooked just right, and I would go back just for the pasta, The steak tagliata was another highlight. The steak was seasoned and tender, and I would recommend.
Ate here for lunch during a conference, the food was great.  I wish I could have tried more from the menu.
Had the meatball pizza which was just okay.  Not anything special.  Service was decent.  Not a place I would go out of my way for but as it's just not special.
Pizzas comme en Italie, buonissime ! Pâte à pizzas fine, anchois frais, cadre à l'italienne dans un des plus beaux hôtels de vegas. Service rapide et prix raisonnables, une bonne adresse à vegas!
Horrible service!! We just walked out after waiting 20 minutes for someone to come by to order drinks. Either they are short staffed or the manager needs to get fired here.

The food was decent, but the service is probably the worst I've ever came across! Our waiter MIGUEL was so rude and far from attentive. He never checked up on us, not even to get our check, he walked by so many times to check the tables around us, but neglected ours. If you are looking for a good dining experience stay far away from this place.

The Otto at the Venetian hotel in Vegas. Every dish here was amazing! The pizza from the kids menu with black olives (the crust was crunchy and the sauce so good). The kale salad and the Branzino dishes were full of flavor. The chocolate gelato, yummy. Only the tiramisu was so so

This was a good experience. The pasta was good.  Meatballs were a little hard.  Pizza was crispy and yummy, just the way I like it.   Service was very good as well. Sat on outside patio area and enjoyed the ambiance of the palazzo.  Very nice evening.

I don't understand Las Vegas.... Food horrible and so many big name just for tv.... Otto is one of them! Mozzarella caprese Fritta???? Tasted and looked like little pieces of crap! Nice location... Probably the best.... The name on the back.... Batali... Is he really a chef??? Horrible Horrible shame on you!
I had Margarita Pizza which was delicious....the Tiramisu was awesome!....they make everything from scratch.....good service! Highly recommended!

While the ambiance was nice, the food was only mediocre and very overpriced. We had the margarita pizza and arugula salad, and while the salad was very good, the pizza was bland and unappealing. Definitely not worth $21 for a 10 inch pizza. Stick with Dominos.

Extremely disappointing. Waiter was the worst I have had in a long time. Appetizers were missing ingredients. Pizza was okay but did not meet expectations. Seriously, Sbarro's would have been a better choice. Not worth the $100 meal.

Neapolitan pizza is amazing here.  Perfect amount of toppings with fresh sauce and fresh mozzarella.  The bottom crust was crunchy with a wonderfully chewy end crust.    We also tried some of the appetizers:   Cauliflower Frittelle  and  Frittelle di Prosciutto.   Frittelle di Prosciutto was good but very salty.   Cauliflower Frittelle  was also very good, but the portion size was large and we had to stop ourselves from over eating.  Service was a little slow, especially for being lunchtime on a weekday.  However, we would go back because the pizza was just that good!

Not very impressed.  As far as Vegas hotel fare goes it was ok.  I had the braised pork ravioli and a nice Barbera.  The ravioli was thin with way too much sauce.  The Barbera was wonderful, but when  got to the bottom of the glass I drank in a large wad of sediment.  My glass had been the last poured from the bottle and they weren't paying attention.  I then had the tiramisu and some coffee.  The tiramisu tasted nice, but the mascarpone mixture was the consistency of peanut butter.  It was so thick it was sticking in my mouth.  We didn't see much of our waitress, but the busboy was incredible.  He was very attentive and even helped us with more coffee when our waitress had disappeared.  Not the worst italian food, but for their prices it was very disappointing.

Let down.  I really wanted to like this Mario Batali joint.  It is obvious that it survives as a result of the celebrity name, and its beautiful location.  Had the salami as an appetizer - terrible - grainy, and devoid of flavor Capponata - Took chunky and sweet Margarita(sp?) Pizza - $24 bucks for a personal sized pizza with barely crusty crust?  I have had NY Pizza, tons of brick oven pizza, and this doen't rate close in quality to most of it.    An overpriced(typical of Vegas) celebrity restaurant that is worthy of a pass
Their prosciutto bruchetta is amazing order it! They also have a great selection of meats and cheeses. Wine menu by the glass starts at $11. Good service.
Loved the casual atmosphere and beautiful surroundings. The drinks and meat and cheese selections are wonderful. Great service

This place was really cute and busy. My mother and I ate lunch here and everything was really good. She had the meatballs and I did a pizza. The only gripe I have, is the pizza was a little over cooked. Our server was so friendly and very attentive.

I was disappointed with the other Batali/Bastianich joint, so I was a bit hesitant on coming here.  Unfortunately that wasn't the case.  I sat down with friends and ordered a corkscrew pasta dish with pulled lamb, mint, and tomatoes.  I was hoping that the sheer simplicity would work.  Luckily, it did, and it was delicious.  The pairing with the house red also helped quite a bit as well.  Our server was pretty cool and helped to curb any suggestions that our group had throughout the evening.  My only gripe were the stupid pigeons who decided to camp on the fake balcony, which was right over my entree.  I had to move the dish out the way several times in hopes that I wouldn't have a poop surprise on my plate.  Fortunately, it wasn't the case.  Overall, I enjoyed this more than the other B/B place, and would definitely come back ... as long as the pigeons were somewhere else.

This restaurant has become a family favorite! Always a wonderful experience. We celebrated my husband's birthday last night. Service was excellent, staff was friendly and the food, as always was superb!  Lasagna, pasta a la Norma, salmon and a beautiful assortment of cheeses and cured meats. High quality in a wonderful setting! Italian perfection!! Can't wait to go back.

We had a leisurely late afternoon lunch here after a day of shopping and it was just perfect.  Fun location in the fake St. Mark's Square at the Venetian.  The food is really yummy -- we had the black spaghettini with calamari, charcuterie & cheese pates, and these awesome vegetable sides that were perfectly cooked (parsnips, eggplant, and beets).  Service is friendly, helpful, and attentive. Mario Batali does not disappoint!
The short rib ravioli has no cheese. Only stuffed with meat and topped with sauce. It's okay. But the penne is better. Nothing spectacular for what it's worth.
Greeting- yes Vibe- Italian  Service- good to slow Prices - expensive Food Pizza is ok and expensive over $20 for an individual pie Black spaghetti and meatballs was interesting  WIGB? No

I've eaten here several times but never disappoints. Although you can never take from dining in Italia, this gets close. Love when. they offer the guanciale. Have an order of prosciutto and buratta and you are transported. Finish with an amaro and homemade gelato and enjoy.

Above average for a casino restaurant.  We were fortunate to snag a table for dinner right along the rail in the "courtyard" meaning that we enjoyed the string quartet that was playing as well as the incomparable people watching that Vegas casinos offer. If you were with a significant other, it would be pretty romantic - all the atmosphere of St Mark's Square in Venice without the worry of being shit on by hordes of pigeons. As it was, I was here for work and had to confine myself to enjoying the fashion choices of the tourist hordes.  Wine - well, an enoteca generally means "wine bar" where the choices are many and the price is reasonable. This is Vegas - the choices are many, but the prices are mighty. That said, I did have the best prosecco I can recall (bone dry) for a relatively reasonable $12/glass.  Food - I had a hard time choosing between pizza and meatballs. But at the end of the day, who doesn't want to sample Mario Batali's balls, amirite? All ball jokes aside, my meal was really good - if meatballs could ever be described as "light", these were. I liked that they were served with polenta rather than pasta. And the serving was generous - 3 large meatballs. Personally, I can only handle two balls at a time. (sorry, couldn't resist)  Side - Cold peas with prosciutto & mint - absolutely delightful.  Service - slightly above average. We didn't see her a lot but no real issues either.  Two further questions:  Does "Otto" mean something in Italian? Otherwise, it kind of seems odd to name a restaurant after the bus driver on the Simpsons.  This place is located across the piazza from a Wolfgang Puck joint. Do the servers here fight it out after hours a la the Sharks and the Jets? Because that would be pretty awesome.

I brought my honey back here last week, mainly because I wanted him to try some of the amazing cheeses on the cheese plate.  I also wanted to try something different.  We arrived a bit earlier than our 5 o'clock reservation and I didn't see my awesome waiter from last time, Jeffrey, so I didn't bother to ask to be in his section.  That sadly was an error.  He did show up right around 5 but it was too late by then.  The waiter I got assigned wasn't nearly so attentive (he actually disappeared partway through our meal) and to be honest, much as I hate to say it, I could barely understand his accent so I didn't ask as many questions about the menu as the first time.  We ordered five cheeses - the three I had last time plus gorgonzola and parmesano reggiano.  I love blue cheeses but the gorgonzola was actually a bit too strong for me, which I found really surprising.  My favorites this time were the aged goat cheese and the parmesan.  I still love the cherries that come with that dish.  For entrees my honey ordered the lasagna and I ordered the sausage and peppers pizza.  I had a bite of his lasagna and thought it was very good.  The pizza alas was just mediocre.  The sausage didn't have much flavor and it was sparse on cheese, though the cheese was good quality, and to be frank I didn't find the sauce very flavorful.  I preferred the goat cheese pancetta pizza from last time, which was different enough from a 'normal' pizza that I wouldn't compare the two directly.  For dessert we tried the cherry shortcake which was pretty good.  The cherries were sadly not the same ones as on the cheese plate which is what we were hoping for, but were more like queen anne cherries.  It was still a decent dessert but didn't hold a candle to the amazing pear sorbetto from last time which alas was not offered on this visit.  I still like the restaurant overall but I'm feeling like it's very hit or miss, with some potential for greatness that isn't always realized.

This place is terrible. Bad service, our waiter went MIA several times during our 2 hour dinner on Friday night.  Our food was cold, the past was way undercooked.  The pizza  was also cold, very skimpy on toppings, no sauce. Tasted like a dry cracker.  Nobody in our party of 6 liked this place.

The food was pretty good, service was poor. My sausage and peppers pizza was tasty, and my friends' meals (braised short rib ravioli and veal ricotta meatballs) were fantastic. Our server was very nice when he was around but was not attentive. Took three of us almost two hours to complete a meal, and in the end our credit cards were not even split correctly with the amounts we had written down on the check. Overall not bad, but I don't think I'll be going back.

I was very disappointed by this restaurant. The service was good, but the food was not very tasty and the wine list, while very good, was more expensive than the dinner! It felt like an over-priced tourist restaurant.
Delicioso, buen ambiente, excelente servicio y buen precio. Uno de mis must do en Las Vegas.
some of the best pizza ever, beef brisket meatballs on a well thought out base consisting of high end parm slices and chili oil. great tuna salad too! big fan of both chefs, this was a treat.

Mario Batali - please read and fix this in your restaurant.  Otto's has an eviable location and whilst staying at the Venetian hotel with my 70 year old mother-in-law and twin 7 year old boys, convenience and an easily acquired view (of the Venetian square) counted for a lot.  Unfortunately, our dining experience was ruined by the staff's refusal to provide a side of pasta with marinara sauce to my mother-in-law!  She's from back east, so she's used to family style Italian places where one gets a side of pasta with a main course. They had the audacity to suggest we purchase another entree of spaghetti and meatballs for $23!  I went escalated to the manager and received the same response. I was told at one point that because the food is prepared in a kitchen that's not actually on the immediate premises, custom orders are not possible. It surprises me that an Italian restaurant with these price tags wouldn't be able to produce a plate of "pasta with marinara" by request. Given the sponsor chefs (Mario Batali, Joe Bastianich) are of such notoriety, I was surprised and disappointed.  Maybe they treated us poorly because we had our 7 year old twin boys with us or we didn't look sufficiently sophisticated.  (You try looking good after chasing 7 year olds all day and dealing with your M.I.L). Very disappointing.

We couldn't decide where to have a nice Italian dinner in the Venetian and after reviewing the menu, we decided to try this restaurant.  The hostesses were friendly and one showed us to a table in the 'outdoor' seating area that was located towards the end and away from all the noise.  Our assistant waiter came with bread and water quite promptly.  Our waiter was friendly and casual.  I ordered a bellini which was not a slushy drink but still good.  The bread was good and I like how it came with the dipping oil and vinegar.  They brought out 3 pieces for 2 people which I didn't quite understand why they didn't have even number of pieces.  But I guess that was all that would fit on the late.    The menu contains more wine choices that food so if you want to try a different wine, this would be a great place to go.  I had the rigatoni ragu with veal and pork shredded in tomato sauce with the pasta.  The portion wasn't too big but just right and saved enough room for dessert.  I liked the meat as it was different from meatballs but filling.  During the meal, we asked for more bread and the assistant waiter was very quick to respond to our request and told us to let him know if we wanted more.  For dessert we had the tiramisu.  It's not the usual tiramisu that I've had but it was good and I liked the espresso gelato.  It's definitely pricey at $14 though.   It wasn't a cheap meal, $21 for pasta, $12 for drink, and then dessert  but it was a great atmosphere and meal.

Wellllll, I'm underwhelmed!   I ordered the Penna alla Norma and it should be renamed penna alla boring!  Not too tastebud tantalizing!  My husband ordered the veal and ricotta meatballs with polenta.  He claimed it was "good, just not exceptional."  We then ordered gelato which was soupy!  Not a thick rich consistency that clings to your tongue and the roof of your mouth!  Flavors were thin!  Lastly, the stools at the bar were uncomfortable!!!  I won't be back!

The food was good but not outstanding.  We had the beef tagliatelle.  It was flavorful but I thought the meat was a little tough. I love arugula but there was so much filling the plate that it became boring.   The salad and spaghetti and meatballs were fine. The wine was a bit overpriced but tasty and a pretty good pour. The atmosphere was lively but not exactly comfortable.   I guess I have been comparing all restaurants to my favorite in london...good food a little pricey but I always leave wanting to lick the plate and the atmosphere there is just the right mix of comfy and cool that I am almost more happy to go by myself...I want that experience all the time!!!... The service at otto was  good just a tiny bit off from excellent. Thank you rocco!

Located inside the shopping area inside the Venetian, this Batali restaurant was awesome.  Most people that dine here are able to sit on the patio so that they can people watch while they enjoy some delicious food.  We didn't make reservations and were seated inside the wine room.  Only complaint was that it was pretty stuffy inside which I thought was weird considering the amount of wine they had nearby on the shelves.  As we were browsing the menu, a server brought over the water along with some bread http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/otto-enoteca-pizzeria-las-vegas#BybPUIq7bTLkopItCcsTXA.    We opted to share a few appetizers which included the sweet potato croccheta and the spiedini http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/otto-enoteca-pizzeria-las-vegas#64U553oYf5iPiEJNBYzcSw.  Both were fried to a dark golden brown and were tasty.  Highly recommend the spiedini as it came out hot and was like eating a gooey cheese melt.  Next appetizer we shared was an assorted vegetable antipasti which comprised of the following marinated olives, eggplant caponata, roasted parsnips, roasted cauliflower, and the otto pickles.  All were tasty but be warned that the pickles have a very very strong vinegar taste to them which people may/may not like.  We then shared the prosciutto and arugula pizza http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/otto-enoteca-pizzeria-las-vegas#vreDtfVTfDNJCRA3SZqRGQ.  I cannot tell you how good this pizza was!!  The crust was crispy throughout and combination of prosciutto, mozarella cheese and their sauce was amazing!  This is where the vast majority of pizzerias that serve thin crust pizzas fail as it's soggy in the middle of the pizza.  Next up was the gemelli pasta which consisted of their homemade sausage with broccoli rabe bits http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/otto-enoteca-pizzeria-las-vegas#6Q7NoNkvAMfRK_jyyFYILA.
