The sausage once again did not disaapoint and was simply awesome.  The pasta was cooked perfectly al dente and the broccoli rabe and sausage combination was to die for.  Batali did not disappoint once again and I wouldn't hesitate to dine here again when in Vegas.

With the name change (formerly Enoteca San Marco) came a blow to the quality of this comfortable eatery.  The menu is the same.  You get to select the number of items you want to try or share from a well chosen list of cheeses, cured meats, salads, fried items and if you like, add pastas or pizzas to your starter.  Fun.  Wines by the glass are still 250ml pours making them a great deal.  The slip in quality is found in the service and quality of the prepared items.  I am a regular and several managers and servers know me so I have never had any problem with service however, another guest sitting at the bar next to me was told that she had to pay $5 if she wanted an extra marinated cherry with her cheese course.  Another asked for additional olive oil for his bread, his server told him that they give you enough for your bread and wanted to be sure that he would not waste the additional oil.  As for my food the fried cauliflower was heavily coated in uncooked batter and the pasta was extremely salty.  I sent the pasta  back but thanks to a language barrier (the busser did not speak good English), my dish returned with NO salt.  Oh well.  They took it off the check and comped my wine so I was satisfied.  This is still a good place for a quick bite, especially if you want to enjoy the show that is the Venetian.

A harrowing experience that I have never forgotten   On December the 27th, 2010, my family and I decided to eat at this establishment, a quaint and attractive corral of tables inside the Venitian. Thinking that pizza was universal enough and since I love cheese, I ordered the pizza quatro fromaggi. It should be called the "pizza quatro dimone."   While my fellow diners were privileged to partake in good and tasteful victuals, my experience was horrifically different. The "pizza" arrived, a thin yet textureless crust more bland than a saltine cracker. Oh, what I would have given for the remainder of that meal to have been so bland!   The sauce was somehow simultaneously as bitter as orange juice served in an aluminum cup and as sweet as frosting, smothered atop the pizza in a bloody masacre-like fashion. The surface of the pizza would have been only sauce, but for one horrific, greasy, formless globule of cheese in the center of each piece. I'll never know if it was the Tallegio or the Cacio that fell me.    And here, I start to go blank. The memories, the horror...  The taste of bile and frosting mixed with locker-room sweat and sourness, mixed with the at once rosey yet musky dirty-water "Esscence of the Venitian" scent wafting through the air ducts. I could taste nothing but that for days. Every food I ate for the rest of the day tasted of IT.   Now I sit here, more than two years later, still remembering every once in a while that terrible taste, that permiating aroma. I can still smell it on-call, just by remembering.   Shame on you, Mario Batalli. In all of your culinary genious, you have hidden ONE fateful dish on your menu, making for a cruel game of russian roulette.   Although you may partake of its benignant friends, BEWARE of this pizza and the evil it portends!
I have eaten at a number of Mario Batalli restaurants and like the others both the food and service was exceptional. I had the linguini with mussels and saffron.

They have gluten free pasta and it's delicious! I left satisfied for under $15 and in my option that is a great deal for gluten free and being in Las Vegas. We even got to see/hear the musicians play while we ate.

This is our first visit, they had a strong start with a poor finish. The only reason that I rated it a 3 star is that the food was on point.   Believe it or not, I have more grace for a miss on food than a miss on service. After placing our appetizer, dinner and wine order, service was scarce. I had to pour the wine myself for my wife and I, which should not happen. Our wine glasses were empty for a while. What's worse is that the server was aware we were celebrating our anniversary, and we were neglected most of the evening.  If you want good food and mediocre, at best, service, this is your place.
Ok food, and Ok service.  Mario Batali should not associate his name with a restaurant at this mid level.

I can't give half stars...but if I could...I would give this place a 2.5. I would have to say the service was very good. Our server was very knowledgable about the menu and suggested some good appetizers and entrees, well at least he made it seem like they were good. There were 9 in our party. We ordered a cheese platter with some nice condiments like apricot marmalade, cherries and honey that went amazingly well with the ricotta cheese. I don't remember what other cheeses we ordered, I think there were like 8 different kinds on there. They were cheeses that you could buy at Trader Joe's or Whole Foods or even possibly at an Italian Deli, which I'm sure would be way better. That platter alone was about $30 and we ordered 2 different pizzas....might I say I had better. I would prefer a Pizza from Pizzamania in Long Beach, Ca. over the pizza from Otto.  My boyfriend and I had a Grilled Pork Chop for our entree, the server suggested for the pork to be cooked medium rare...but when we got it it was well done and dry. I'm just glad there were juices from the pork that I could dip my meat in. I didn't want to send it back because we've waited long enough for our food. All the other pastas that everyone else in our party ordered looked like below avg pastas. I've had waaaay better pasta cooked by yours truly. Like any other restaurant in Las Vegas, everything was over priced for the way it tasted. It wasn't anything special. It's not a place that I would recommend to others. I never like Mario Batali that Orange Croc wearing chef...he seems to be way to over arrogant for the menu at Otto. I don't think I would go there again. Just Sayin!!!

We went to Otto for lunch a few weeks back. We'd eaten there a few times before and had really enjoyed it. I'm a fan of Joe and Mario and mama Lydia. Does Lydia know that you put Boquerones on the Pizza Romana? I just can't imagine that anyone thought that a Spanish White Anchovy in vinegar was appropriate for a Pizza with big gobs of undercooked Mozzarella. That Pizza was undercooked, gooey, and had vinegary fish on it! Yuck! Our other dish, the grilled Radicchio with smoked mozzarella on the other hand was completely overcooked. The Radicchio charred and ashy, the cheese crispy and sweaty. Big Disappointment. Service was very good. I did say something to manager about Boquerones being a strange item with undercooked cheese and she said that it has always been that way. hmmm. Anyway, very expensive and very unremarkable.

Tried this play a while back, and it was really amazing! I love the locAtion of this restaurant and the food. I remember having an eggplant dish and it was cooked to perfection. I really want to try this place again

This was my top pick when planning our visit to Vegas, and it didn't let me down! I had the braised pork shoulder which was unbelievable- I'm still dreaming about it. My husband got a pizza, which was large enough to bring about half of it back to the hotel for a late night snack.   The service was as great as the food, and we were "outside" so we got to watch a performance on the stage in the square as we ate our lunch, which only added to the experience.   We had such a great time and a great meal. So thankful for the experience.
Salami Cotto. Formaggi. Arugula and Shaved Parmigiano. I cannot remember which other salad. Sausage & Peppers Pizza. Lasagna. Gelato. :(  Still deliciouso!  :)

Good service, good location and good Italian food with nice large glasses of Wine! Try any of the Yummy Pasta's or the perfectly cooked to order Pizza's .  It was my 10th year running to this place when I'm in Vegas. I enjoy coming to Otto because they try to seat you as soon as possible. Unlike other restaurants here at the~Venetian which gets me so frustrated at times.

Good food and service.  However, expect to walk away hungry in an hour.  1. Grilled Radicchio with Smoked Mozzarella - If you're expecting something light, pass on this one.  It looked like lasagna.  Basically, burnt leaf smothered in melted cheese.  2. Prosciutto Arugula - Light and hit the spot.  Chewy crust, crispy middle. 3. Sausage & Peppers - Taste exactly like it sounds. 4. Spaghettini - Amazing!  Tons of mushrooms, light flavors.  5.  Lasagna (special) - Must try!

Here for our 4th or 5th group dinner with a party of 10-15. Previously we have always had a lovely time however tonight was truly awful. The only way a wine or water glass was filled was if someone got up from the table to find a staff member. The main courses took over two hours to arrive and were not fully correct when they did. This used to be a 'must go' and has become a 'never again'.

Very very disappointing. I've been here a few times but this was the worst experience I've had in Vegas. I eat at the Otto in ny often. First we ordered a cheese plate ...the condiments the gave us made me think they must be rationing food. It was not enough for the plate we ordered. So we asked for more to which they stated they needed to charge us.....I couldn't even respond i was totally appalled ... We ordered an additional cheese tray and the food runner gave us extra honey. He should be a waiter... Then I decide to defer from the dish i get here and try something different...bad idea. I order linguine and mussles.... I get a dish that has about 7 mussles of which 3 are closed shut...really?  Sent it back and ate after everyone else was done. Definitely off the list we were to aggravated to even get an espresso.
Yup, same great quality as NYC.  The salads are fantastic!

This is a decent spot for some casual dining in the Grand Canl Shoppes in the Venetian. A few years ago this place used to be called Enoteca San Marco and I could honestly say that it boasted the best pizza I've ever had. Unfortunately ownership has since changed and although the menu looks almost identical to its earlier version, the quality has dropped a great deal. As things stand now, Enoteca has 2 things going for it: a good location in the middle of the replica of St. Mark's square which means that you will get a chance to see a performance of the "Phantom" soundtrack and some Italian opera pieces during dinner and that you won't pay an arm and a leg for a meal. The pizzas are about $18-21 each and are sufficient to keep you satiated and  one can easily feed 2 diners if you add an appetizer or 2. I would say the Prosciutto and Goat Cheese pizza is the best, although the last time I ordered it the pizza came out burnt and overloaded with cheese. Do yourself a favor and don't order the Pesto Pizza; it is supremely disappointing. Finally the wine list is (as expected) dominated by Italian vintages but the staff does not offer much in the way of suggestions if you're having trouble deciding. Their pours of wine are also stingy and the waiter made the mistake of using a wide rimmed glass for champagne. If you're not in the mood for pizza, the restaurant offers a limited selection of meats and pasta which are rather standard Italian fare and which you can get for approximately the same price and superior preparation in the nearby Canaletto and Postrio.

I had dinner here a few nights ago, the food was amazing. Cauliflower appetizer was perfectly cooked and the truffle pizza was to die for. The atmosphere was romantic with the lighting and open space, we got sat upon arrival and we're greeted a few minutes later. The rating isn't great because our server was having an off day. I think her name was Sabrina or Serena?  She was nice enough but slow and sort of killed the experience for us. My friends and I are locals and will be back for the food but we will definitely not sit in her section, we all work hospitality and she was too busy to offer recommendations or engage with us, an order taker to the T. But the food was great, drinks were delicious!

It's been awhile since I've given ONE PENNY for tip...but Otto Enoteca Pizzeria did it!  Three stars for the food and one star for the service.  Arrive at the restaurant at 11AM and the entire place was EMPTY so we thought the hostess would be glad to see some customers.  Boy, was I wrong!  She barely cracked a smile as she directed us to the seats.  After we placed our order with the waitress, the breadman came by with a plate of cold bread...didn't even bother to offer some olive oil or cracked black pepper (all the other tables that came after us had those offered tableside).  The waitress was literally one foot away from my wife when she tried to ask her for some olive oil...totally ignored my wife.  She didn't even come by to refill our water.  The last time we saw the waitress was when she shoved the dessert menu right in front of my wife's face...pretty rude.  C'mon, Mario Batali...if you are going to charge $20 for pizza at lunch, you should hire some more pleasant people.    As for the food...mediocre.  Friday's special was the carbonara pizza.  It was a fair dish...the egg was slightly over-cooked.  DO NOT get the artichoke pizza.  The prosciutto they used was completely flavorless and the scariest part is...that more than half of each slice was pure fat!  So, as you bite into the slightly sour (from artichoke...tasted like they are from a can) and spicy (from chilli) pizza slice, you get a mouth full of white, greasy flavorless fat.  Disappointed...prosciutto should be full of flavor!!!    We ate at Le Cirque the night before for Thanksgiving and the service & food were impeccable.  Mr. Batali has too many restaurants in Vegas and the quality is suffering.  Rather than caring about money and hiring rude but cheap servers and using less-than-quality ingredients, maybe he should care more about his customers.

The Service was bad. Our waiter was Condon sending and treated us like this was the first time we had meat and cheese platter. The pizza was burnt around the edges and  the crust was overcooked. Kids Pasta was way overpriced and they forgot the cheese on the cheese and butter topping. This was the worst food we had in Vegas the entire time we stayed.  I feel like I need to go get something to eat after having dinner at Otto's.
Food was eh. Spaghetti with meatballs had tiny little meatballs and was completely overpowered by the taste of basil upon basil upon basil. Portions were small.

this is mario batali's restaurant.  we actually didn't see it before we made the reservations... and i really didn't like the location / atmosphere.  there wasn't any inside seating... all seats were on the cobblestone and outside near the public.    the service was great.  very attentive staff.  the best thing we ate was the veal and ricotta meatballs.$24. it was served with a very light and simple tomato sauce.  the meatballs were tender and delicous and so light.  they were fantastic!  but does not come with any pasta or sides.

So disappointed to see such poor reviews of Otto.  We loved it here.  It was by far the best meal I had in Vegas on this trip.  From the service, to the food, to the ambiance (minus the tables with kids), it was all perfection.    Firstly, we loved our server.  He was so patient and offered us a reasonably priced wine after we described they type of wine we like.  He offered wonderful suggestions and didn't push us to order too much, or too little.    We stared with several appetizers:  ricotta fritters, which were incredible, lentils, way better than I expected them to be...(I wish they sold those at Trader Joe's), and two cheeses which were accompanied by jam and honey to compliment them.  We had a goat cheese and a cow's milk cheese.    By the time we had gotten through the appetizers we were too full to each get a main course.  We were in the mood for pizza and split the eggplant pizza.  The eggplant was shaved thin.  The pizza had red sauce, which I love and the crust was perfectly thin but not so thin that the slice drooped onto your hand.  It was a fantastic pizza.  Finally, for dessert, we had the Otto Sundae.  Real good and made with gelato.

I like to judge Italian restaurants on their margherita pizzas and spaghetti with tomato sauce.  Both of these dishes are very simple, but if done right, can be amazing.  Based upon the server mentioning how small the dishes are, we ordered both, along with a sausage and peppers pizza, and a cheese plate.  The portions were not as small as the waiter said or what other reviewers have mentioned, and we are not exactly lightweights.    We started with a cheese plate of bufala mozzarella, taleggio, and Cypress Grove goat cheese.  The plate was served with bread, cherries, apricot, and most importantly, honey with black truffle.  All three cheeses were great, and I loved the honey with black truffles.  The margherita pizza was very good.  What really made it stand out was how crispy the crust was.  Many pizzas tend to get soggy over time, as the sauce seeps into the crust, but this remained crispy until the end.  The sauce had a nice fresh tomato flavor.  The cheese was good, though I wish it had more of it.  It was not the best margherita I have had, but I would definitely order it again.  The spaghetti and meatballs were good but over salted.  The pasta was cooked perfectly al dente.  The sauce would have been better with about 1/3 less salt.  The meatballs had nice flavor and added a little kick to the dish.  I was hoping the dish would be in the same class as spaghetti at Scarpetta, but it most certainly was not.  The service was great.  Overall, I would eat there again, though I am not particularly anxious to do so.

Why didn't I refer to Yelp, I could have saved myself grief and money?  The location is beautiful and of course I was drawn by the name of the chef who established this restaurant but the experience was disappointing.  My husband and I ordered a salad to split along with a pizza to share, including drinks.  First, I notice others were getting bread with dipping oil while there food was being prepared.  We did not.  What we received was our pizza? No salad, no bread and no water refills. When I asked the server if we'd get our salad he seemed puzzled. A few minutes later the salad and bread appeared, still no water.  So we were sitting in front of all our food at one time.  Not sure about you, but i like to enjoy my salad and then have my entree nice and hot.  By the time we were ready for our entree of course it was cool.  Our server offered to reheat it and we accepted.  A while later the pizza was brought back to our table BURNT.  I'm not exaggerating, it was three quarts of the crust was burnt, yes black crust. Did no one notice it was burnt?  Why would you serve a burnt pizza? Now we had to ask for a new one.   It would have been so wonderful if our server would have come out and said, the pizza was not to their standards and they will be making us a fresh pizza.  If that would have happened I'd give them a 4 stars!  But it did not and we were put in the awkward position of asking for a new one. We waited and waited and finally received our mediocre pizza. Ugh, such a waste with so many other wonderful Italian restaurants in the local vicinity.   Finally they brought us our pricey check.  I'm okay with pricey when the meal matches, but it did not.  No, offer of compensation for all the mishaps.   If it's a good Italian celebrity meal you're looking for, try Buddy V's Restorante.  We ate there the day prior and it was all around fantastic!

If you crave for a good Italian food and dont want to leave the Vegas strip & also dont want to hurt your pockets, this is the place for you. I like open spaces but the atmosphere here can be a little dense. From the menu, you can not go wrong with classic Italian dishes.

I "Otto" have never gone here. Joe Bastianich is full of shit if he's a Master Chef judge and allows the kind of crap to be served at his restaurant.  I had a pizza which was cold by the time I got it. It wasn't that busy and it didn't take long for our food to arrive so I have to wonder why it was cold.  Quite frankly it tasted like a frozen pizza. Let me rephrase that as it was an insult to frozen pizza - those are usually warm. The crust tasted like cardboard and it looked like they had trouble cutting the slices as it wasn't even cut all the way through.  Cold indifferent service and cold food. Never go back.

I went back and forth on whether to give this place 5 stars or 4.  Not because I don't think it deserves 5, but because I don't want people to think I give top ratings to everywhere I eat.  The truth is, I generally only rate a place if it is really good or really bad.....and I mean reallllly bad.  I don't like being negative or nitpicking unless they have truly offended me or made me feel they have stolen my money.  That being said, I've had nothing but great experiences here and so I can't help but give it the 5 Star treatment.  The cavatappi with lamb ragu dish is mind-blowing. I will admit, I'm a sucker for lamb and this dish is one of the reasons why. I must have had it for the first time 4-5 years ago and it's what keeps me coming back every time I am in Vegas.  The meat and cheese platters are delicious, but a little on the pricey side.  Not that it isn't worth it for the quality you get, but it can really make the bill add up if you go crazy (which I tend to do).  Funny enough, I'd say the one thing you shouldn't get here is the pizzas.  I've had some friends that loved them and some that didn't. I haven't really tried them to be honest.  I just know that if I am going to spend the money to go out in Vegas, I wanna get something I can't normally get everyday. So I'd say if you venture out, try the unique dishes or the charcuterie, you'll love it.  If you just wanna eat some pizza, go find a local pizza spot and you'll walk away with some extra dough.....see what I did there....okay, I'll stop now.

We have eaten here 4-5 times for lunch, and it almost never disappoints. This time we also did the wine flights and would rate those at 3 stars - some hits and misses. But the food is why you are there, it's unpretentious and always good. A great place for a snack or lunch!

BEST THIN CRUST MARGHERITA PIZZA EVER! All thin crust fans must eat here at least once. I was not impressed with Mozza (another Batali pizza place in CA), so my expectations were low. The cheese was insane! It was sooo fresh and creamy and light, it wasn't leathery at all! The dough stayed crisp at the bottom, which I have never seen before. Usually when u first get a thin crust pizza at your table, the first slice is nice and crisp, but the following slices get soggy and buckle when you pick them up. This one held it's shape like a crisp little cracker, but it had that unmistakeable chew of a pizza.  My GF was obsessed and she said it deserves 5 stars. I did wish the sauce had a little sweetness (it's more salty than sweet) and maybe a pinch of oregano. My other favorite Pizza place is Tirovino in LA.   I was really disappointed with the gelato. I ordered the Graham Cracker, Almond Ice Milk, and Dark Chocolate Malt. They were packed in layers in a little metal cup, which irritated me, I wanted to taste each flavor, not have them all mashed together! Wtf?  I tried to separate them as best I could but the flavors were kind of boring and not as interesting as I thought they would be. The ice milk was the best but it wasn't a smooth creamy gelato, more like an icy sorbet. I couldn't taste the malt in the chocolate one at all, Too bad, because I love malt! The graham cracker texture was nice, but this needed a pinch of sea salt or something. I got a cone on the side and it looked fine, but tasted burnt. Anyway, it definitely wasn't worth $13. There are much better desserts to be had in Vegas, like the berry nutella crepes at Paris and Bellagio ;)
Delicious food. I had my kids and it worked out perfectly with the entertainment right there.

Extremely disappointing service.  The 2 girls who are the hostesses had very poor customer service skills and  they wer both ugly to boot - Friday, Sept 2nd.  Had a reservation and wanted a table by the rails and they ship us to timbuktu and when I asked for a closer table so that we can see more of hte "square" they acted as though this was the greatest incovenience.  And to punish us, took 20 minutes to set this up and all others were booked.  then the bus boy was stupid and we did not get our bread until 10 minutes into the meal when our salad was being served.  The food was great and reasonable but the by the glass wine selections were very poor and over priced.  But these 2 ugly girls should be fired for their very poor service - not a great first impression for this restaurant - one star is even over-rated - should have zero stars.

Came to Otto after dinner for drinks. I took a brief look at the cocktail menu and quickly decided that I wanted to try a few of their signature cocktails. I ended up trying quite a few. I started off with the iWhiskey and my friend got a Otto New York. Both were amazing. Decided to try to Montenegro which is apparently an Italian traditional drink that you're supposed to have after a large meal. I'm glad I tried it but I wasn't super fond of it. Since it was an Italian restaurant, I HAD to try the limoncello and I was pleasantly surprised. It was delicious! The service was excellent. The bartender Rico was super easy to talk to & well versed in his drinks. Fhaye was such a great host as well, taking the time to explain the drinks and the history behind them. I'm definitely going to come back soon to try the food!!

Big fan of Mario.  Went to his NYC restaurant before he was famous. Otto has a nice, lively outdoor area but we opted for indoors for a more intimate evening.  The decor was nice but a little too formal for a bistro.  The Margherita pizza was evcellent, better than what we had in Rome.  The gemelli pasta with brocolli rabe and housemade sausage was really flavorful but the pasta itself was too al dente for us.  We thought they should have offered to shave some fresh parmesan on the pasta dish but they didn't.  The appetizer fritti arancine (fried rissoto) was excellent; the fritti di Prosciutto was not as good.  Pistachio and dark chocolate malt gelato was as good as it gets; really smooth, rich and flavorful.  We found the wine by the glass and by the ounce way too pricey; a 4 ounce glass of their middle of the road white and red cost as much as our entres.

The food was okay but the service was so bad I took away a star. Every time I looked for our waiter, he was talking to the hostess or looking at his phone. Also, he talked us in to ordering two pizzas instead of the one we had planned on bc he said that they weren't big enough to feed two. Unless you're starving, they're plenty big for two.... especially if you order a bruschetta. Overall I feel like it was a wasted $60. Pretty disappointing to me.

It had been a dream of mine to dine at Mario Batali & Bastianch's fabulous Italian restaurant Otto Enoteca Pizzeria in  St. Mark's Square at the spectacular Venetian 5 star resort since I saw photos of it on Foursquare,  Yelp and on their Web site.   I took my friend there last night as an early birthday present to myself and everything from the Caprese Ensalata appetizer with creamy homemade mozzarella to my main course of Ravioli Brassata, to the wonderful French bread dipped in the highest quality balsamic vinegar I have ever tasted with  extra Virgin olive oil, was fabulous.  Our 2 waiters were knowledgeable and knew how each dish was prepared, which added to my appreciation of each dish as well. The atmosphere was truly breathtaking as well and hearing the opera singers, who were very talented, was a total extraordinary sensory experience!   Paulette Motzko Food Writer, Photographer, Nevada Resident

Over the years, Otto Pizzeria at the Venetian Piazza San Marco has been one of my favorite lunch places to hit while in Vegas.  It's in a big wide open area with high ceilings painted to look like the sky so it really gives you a feeling of being at the real Piazza San Marco - actually better since its AC, not in the direct sun, no mega crowds and clean :)  That being said I really used to love the bruschetta there.  The standard bruschetta, not the daily "special of the day" bruschetta they serve now.  That and maybe either the bread changed or I'm a little pickier about the bread or dough.    The pic is attached but the garlic, honey, prosciutto looks and tastes like ham on a big jelly baguette.  Not what I was expecting and disappointing.   So I usually have some kind of pizza and really felt like a meat lovers so requested a salami and prosciutto combo.  I was warned (and should have listened) that the salami is aged and has a strong, gamey taste to it.  Wasn't a good choice but my bad.  The second thing that was disappointing was that the pizza wasn't hot or fresh.  Tasted almost like it was reheated - and not reheated enough.  Really disappointing as you can totally tell when you're eating old leftover pizza...  That was two disappointments for the food.  I still love the atmosphere and the service - the busser, waiter and host were all tremendous with excellent service.  They just don't reheat or cook the food.  Overall, if you're at the Venetian, you've gotta eat is the Piazza San Marco... But you might want to try someplace else.

There were 6 of us on our way to see BAZ for the 2nd time at the Venetian and the big question is always where do we go to eat for dinner? We had all intentions of going to Trattoria Reggiano, however a friend of our mentioned Otto, and a friend she was indeed! We started with a large antipasto plate, filled with salami's olives, mortadella, different cheeses, porchetta and prosciutto. The bread was fabulous and thy brought some a couple of jams all just wonderful. The best dish of the night was probably the pork porterhouse, the taste was so delicious and the presentation looked like labyrinth. Others had the Veal and Pork Meatballs, Rigatoni alla Napolitana and the Eggplant Lasagnette all very good. The ambience is fun and our Server Robert was excellent

I was really excited to try a Mario Batali restaurant since I am such a big fan. It was a little disappointing, it wasn't horrible but it wasn't amazing either.   Bread sticks were brought to our table along with some actual bread and some olive oil and balsamic vinegar. We started off with some Cauliflower Frittelle  which was delicious! I got the Linguine with Prawns and my hunnie got one of the Pizzas. Both these dishes were okay nothing to rave about really. My prawns were nice and big but the whole dish itself was a little bland. The Pizza was okay I have had way better. I got the Lemon Meringue Pie for dessert which was way too sour, it was like a punch in the mouth.   Overall Otto's was rather underwhelming and expensive for what you get, not to sure we will be back.

Stayed recently for a few days in vegas at the venetian and tried this place one night. Not really impressed the best thing we had was appetizer of the bruschetta with the wild mushrooms.  Myself and a friend ordered the spicy clam linguinie past taste like it was not even done and the clams did not taste very fresh at all. There were not too many clams in my dish and many of them did not open which usually means they are bad.  The other friend we were with ordered the pork chop which came out drenched in balsamic vinegar my friend was not very impressed with this as most of the dish tasted like the vinegar.  If I go back to vegas will definitely not be back here. Do yourself a favor and visit another restaurant this place is not cheap and the food is not worth even mcdonalds prices.

came here for my bday dinner pt 3 i liked the dim lightning inside the venetian & the sky wallpaper view & we had a snug lil table in the corner in the exterior of the restaurant - apps had the fried bread thing w/ marinara w/ cheese was yumm entree had the clam angel hair in white wine tried the spaghetti & meatballs & the goat cheese pizza xtra thin crust which i like! =] yay mario batali!
Food here is a blast. Ambience is spectacular. All the staff including manager are very friendly. I am gonna come here again and again.

The ambiance for Otto is great but I cant say the same for the food.  My friends and I ordered the spaghetti and meatballs, ravioli,  lasagna,  margherita pizza and was truly disappointed with the presentation and flavors.   Everything we ate was too salty and needed several rounds of water to wash down the taste.  For quality of food that is being served,  the price is outrageous.   Scarpetta at The Cosmopolitan is  a better choice if you are looking for good italian food.

I had a early dinner with friends and family on Friday March 4th 2016, my friend order a pizza which was ok, the calamari were so salty we couldn't eat them, we told the waiter and nothing was done. Meatballs so so and the short ribs ravioli were also salty, we quess the cook was not in a cooking mood.. The only good food 2 of my friends had was the special shrimp scampi. We ask if they had a house wine, our waiter brought wine that was good but not a 21 dollars a glass, he never told us the  price! We are in no way cheap but 21 dollars for a small glass is crazy, we could have just brought the bottle! Won't ever eat there again! New York has better Italian restaurants!!! The waiter didn't even apologize for the salty food!

We wanted a lighter dinner after a heavy lunch earlier that afternoon. First, bread was served with olive oil on request. My parents and I shared a caprese, butternut squash ravioli and a pepper and sausage pizza. Comparing the dinner to my experience in actual Italy, Otto unfortunately falls short. What made Otto stand out however was the freshness of the individual ingredients. The cheese and tomatoes on the caprese was great. The squash stood out in the ravioli, and the dough and the peppers on the pizza was just as tasty. I can not say that it quite reached the levels of Authentic Italian flair (judging by the price, that was their goal), but for what it serves it does so quite competently.

Otto Enoteco Pizzeria's was delicious. We went here for a friend's birthday party, and it was great, we had the back room to ourselves, which was nice. In addition, the thin crusted pizza came out perfectly. We had a veggie one and a pepperoni one, both were delicious. Our friend's also ordered the cheese platter, which could easily be shared with 3-4 people easily. It wasn't that great, so you could easily get another appetizer instead. But the atmosphere and pizza are great here.

Service was very good. Knowledgeable waiters, attentive servers. For the service 5 stars. The margaritas pizza was very good, but caprese salad not made with the the expected fresh tomatoes. They were marinated.  Lemonade with rosemary and sparking water tasty drink. Waiter made us boiled plain pasta for baby and it was delicious pasta on its own plain. Made in Italy. Goat cheese pizza too rich tasting. 3.75 stars.

This is a mall pizzeria with a fancy name behind it. The pizza was ok, but I hoped for better. The wild mushroom bruschetta was one of the worst things I've been served in Las Vegas; the bread was charred, the mushrooms were cold and slimy (it was disgusting).     The service was pretty mediocre too; the server asked if we liked the bruschetta and we told him no. He was in complete disbelief and sort of put us on the defensive when he said "i mean... I can see what I can do about it". We told him we weren't going to worry about it, but we explained that we weren't going to lie about finding it disgusting and we thought they should know. It was pretty much the last time we saw him until the bill was dropped (and no; he didn't do anything about the bruschetta).
The best thing about this restaurant is the wine list.  The pizza comes in second. The rest of my party agreed that the pasta was deficient.

We had the pizza for lunch here and i even struggled to give this place two stars. I have not been to a Mario Bartoli restaurant that I have really liked ever.  The pizza was below average, way too much sauce and not enough cheese, but more importantly it just did not taste very good.
Love Batali's food in general ... So I'm a bit biased. Would have given this 4 stars for food, but the Venetian ambiance made it better.

OVERVIEW Good view of the St Marks Square statue performances but pasta too salty to enjoy.   Just realized that this was a pizzeria, so my review is one star higher considering we ordered pasta.   FOOD Had the Spaghetti alla Chitarra, Penne all Norma, and Broccoli.   The only thing going for the spaghetti allá chitarra is that it had a bit of a kick. Each bite was a mouthful of sand, I don't think they even rinsed the clams. I think I may have chipped a tooth (jk). This was extremely salty, even more salty than my review.  Had we not been famished from exploring the strip all day, we would not have eaten it.  Penne allá Norma was decent, but not particularly memorable. Ingredients tasted fairly fresh.   SERVICE Friendly, attentive staff is the primary reason for the stars given.  ATMOSPHERE Good place to catch the performances throughout the day, but Mercato della Pescheria next door has a better, unobstructed view AND a happy hour menu.

Service was great and the food was incredible. Authenticity at its best. The sommelier gave spot on recommendations for wine pairings for our meal. Management was friendly. From beginning to end, great meal.
Food was alright, nothing too special. Service was horrid. No one bothered to check up on us, everyone was rude (even to our toddlers). Would not go again.

Well, I love Otto in LA...unfortunately, this one is not even close to the one in LA...the pizza here was just.....disappointing :(    I did love having a bottle of red wine, a variety of cheeses, meats and olives, while people watching all the crazy people in Las Vegas.  I would definitely come back for just that....but....they aren't actually making any of those ingredients....LOL

We have a table in the food court at Otto's that we have dubbed "our table." Every trip to Vegas has us enjoying wine and pizza for lunch. It is a favorite! We were a little disappointed this time because they were out of pepperoni pizza that they make there so "settled" for the four cheese pizza. The four cheese pizza at Otto's has each cheese separated so none overpowers the others and was very good - heck, we may even order it on purpose next time! I see some of the other reviews not loving the pizza here and maybe we do in some part for the romance of it, but what I really feel is that America's fast food pizzas are thick and greasy and overly saucy, so that a crisp, clean pizza like the ones at Otto's doesn't measure down (not up!) to them. Give it a try, savor the individual flavors and savor the moment, ask for advice on the wine if you need it (the staff is great about that), and enjoy the surrounding architecture.

The service was okay. But the food was extremely bland. Even the zucchini. How do you mess up vegetables? Sauces were $3 extra for tomato. No biggie but again bland. We had to ask for 2 whole bowls of hot peppers to make the pizza edible.

My lady and I dined here on 06/21/17 , approximately around 4-5 pm for their happy hour.   Firstly, the hostess was the rudest, coldest person and the management should be mocked for hiring such a person. During check in, when she asked for my name, she had the audacity to answer a phone call without saying anything to us. Also, when my girlfriend asked where the restroom was located, she was cold and left a bad taste in our mouths.  Second, our waitress was fair but the assistant server was great, kind, and attentive.  Last but not least, after our food was finished we sat for almost 30 minutes without anyone checking on us. I actually had to raise my arm to receive our check.  The food: we ordered the grilled radicchio salad which was different, and some antipasti specials for happy hour. Food was fair but then we did not order a pasta, pizza, or an entree so i can't say with surety.   I'm a firm believer that good food comes with a pleasant environment and warm service. This restaurant had neither.  The bathrooms also had no paper towels which is kind of a disgrace for a decent/fine dining restaurant such as here.

What a disappointment from start to finish. Not only was the service pretty slow but the food was all dry and flavorless. We ordered the grilled radicchio, squash blossoms, pickles, truffle pizza, and the gemelli pasta. Squash blossoms were over fried and had barely any ricotta in them. The pasta was descent but it didn't really have the cheese flavor (or much of any flavor at that). I was so sad! Guess we will just have to stick to B and B only.

My go to place for lunch while in Vegas. I have been numerous times and I find it very consistent, consistently good. This is pretty authentic Italian food. Not the basic American version with heavy sauces and a ladle of sauce on a mound of spaghetti.  While I have not tried the entire menu, I have had the privilege of having several items.  I always start with the Ricotta Fritters. These are crunchy yet creamy deep fried balls of ricotta cheese. I dare you to try and eat just one. I usually follow that up with the Rigatoni with Ragu Napolitana. It is served a bit al dente, so if you prefer softer pasta, ask them to cook it a little longer. The ragu is light with a flavorful blend of shredded veal and pork.  I have also had two different pizzas. The Margherita and the Sausage and Peppers. Both were wood fired with a light crisp crust. I preferred the Margherita. It was so light and fresh. The perfect amount of sauce as to not over power it. It's making my mouth water thinking about it. In the past I have also tried the Ravioli (Butternut Squash with Browned Butter and Sage drizzled on top) and the Gemelli (with Sausage and Broccoli Rabe). Again both were very good. The portions are a bit on the small size, however, they are deceivingly filling.  I have read several reviews that mention they think that the price is a bit high, even for Vegas. I would agree with them. But you must consider the location, ambiance and the Operatic singers and minstrels that are playing and singing in the square.  If you are looking for quiet, you may want to sit inside. If not, the patio is great!  Buon Appetito!

Went on MLK day. No crowds. I have been here on weekends - crazy waiting. I like the food because it is tasty and does not leave you feeling awfully full. Service is good. Ask for the sommelier if you need help pairing a wine with your food. Lamb chops are awesome. I had them medium.

The B & B Boys rock the Las Vegas Strip with their new trio of restaurants.  However, I do have a soft spot in my heart for this little gem in the Venetian Grand Canal Shoppes.  I had the potato, garlic pizza and much to my surprise loved it.  When you visit Otto everyone is Italian.  The pasta, cured meats, pork shoulder, and other small plaates are the way to go here.  The black ink spaghetti with calamari was a masterpiece.  I also had a refreshing lemon meringue desert.  If you want a top notch meal, and have Italian wannabee blood Otto is the place to be seen!  The B&B Boys!!! Las Vegas!
My boyfriend and I always eat here when ever we visit Vegas! Great environment with some classical music! Waiters are very nice and the food comes right away.

I read the reviews and expected ok italian food, but this turned out to be a gem.  its conviniently located in the large open plaza by the gondolas, nice ambience.  The appetizer was delicious, service was good and the entrees didnt dissapoint.  I will return, and I recommend this restaurant.

My number one restaurant to visit in Las Vegas  Daily Bruschetta is always worth to try Pasta and cheese selections are great. Evens though this is pizzaria I wouldn't go for pizza they are just normal without any special flavour
Great pizza and appetizers.  The service was amazing, and the ambiance second to none.  We've been in Vegas three days and have been at Otto's twice already.  Awesome wine selection as well!!

A big thanks to Joe Bastianich and Mario Batali for making my last Vegas meal a memorable one!  From the Moscato to the olives to the arugla salad and my pasta all the way to the coffee and tiramisu, it was divine.  I can't eat for days I'm so full and content!  Everything was seasoned and prepared perfectly.  I felt like the chefs were in the kitchen waiting for my next order.  The tiramisu and coffee are a must.  The staff were very prompt and professional.  You will not run out of refreshments, nor will a finished dish sit ungathered for long.  Bravo!

I have been here before and had a much better experience previously.  While the service was fantastic the food was sub standard.  First the Arancini appetizer was extremely salty.  It could have used much less salt.  Second the Bucatini was also salty.  They refilled my water four times because the food was so salty.  The experience could have been so much better if they just reduced the amount of salt.
I love this place. It definitely feels like you are in an outdoor piazza. The food never disappoints and the staff is extremely knowledgeable about the food, ingredients and wine.

Great food. I had a pizza with truffles that was extraordinary and my companions had various spaghetti items that I would enumerate except for all this wine I drank. We also had a couple wonderful appetizers including a preserved tuna and white beans thing that was amazing, great wine list and there were all these post-dinner "digestives" - nasty Italian liqueurs that helped you digest if they didn't kill you first. The service was great and it wasn't outrageously expensive. I'm docking it a star because it is in a mall. A high-falutin mall, but still, all the passers-by do detract from the ambiance. Despite that I'd come back in a hot second. Go Mario!

Ok, I came to this place expecting nothing less than GREAT, I was disappointed, the restaurant was beautiful, the service was fine but the food was so salty that we only took two bites, I never complaint to the wait staff and I didn't do it this time either, but when they came to clear our plates and saw that we barely touch our food they didn't ask if anything was wrong, just assume we weren't hungry? I'm really disappointed... :-(

Went here for lunch, loved the pizza's but was underwhelmed by appetizers.  Service was definitely a bit slow, had to constantly ask for the waiter.  The truffle pizza was delicious!  The artichokes were super bland, there were onions, olive oil and cheese but they needed flavor, literally you could buy a jar at a supermarket and it would have tasted better.  I love artichokes but these were sad.  The pork was on point though.    Also had a bloody mary which was so-so, the one at the Public House was phenominal and it was hard to compare.  Overall, stick to simple dishes and don't expect much from things other than pizza.

Got a Peroni draft beer at the bar  , somehow this  draft is the best I've ever tried ,  I tried another Peroni draft elsewhere, but somehow this seems the best, something is different about it here in Vegas, try it yourself at the Otto bar and you might agree with me , they have a happy hour peroni 2-1 but I'm not sure , I just saw a sign outside Otto , I a small order cheese  platter for $10, there are many choices to pick ,  you ll see it on the food menu, they throw in some fresh bread , it goes will with the beer.

The cheese platter was great,  but the spaghetti and meatballs was awful! The sauce tastes like it came from a jar,  and the meatballs were tiny with no flavor.  Definitely not worth the price.  I should've just ordered more cheese.

Fresh. Flavorful. Simple. Delicious. The food is made from some of the highest quality ingredients anywhere in America. This is a restaurant for foodies. The cured meats, the pasta, the pizzas, the pork shoulder, the Osso Buco, were all just fantastic. Talk to the staff, nearly all of them are food geeks. If you like really good hand made food from only the highest quality ingredients, go. Also, the manage Ralph Treszi is one of the most accommodating and professional people I have met in the food and beverage industry. I have been nearly ten times (I found it through the Molto Vegas Farmer's Market) and will continue as long as the quality and service stay they same.

Over rated. I've had far better pizza in Provincetown , MA (spiritus pizza) and in Hudson, NY ( Baba Louie's). Otto's pizza was boring at best.  We also had a BAD experience with the bill. The bill came, we paid the bill and gave a generous tip. We lingered, chatting and the head waiter came over and announced that they had forgotten a bottle of wine and that part of our table owed an extra 80 dollars. The couple that had wine disputed the bill. I had beer , so I left.  If you go, study your bill closely, pay it and GO. Do not linger!  Seriously, the pizza is over rated. You are paying for a name.  (I loved China Poblano at the Cosmopolitan. Mex/Chinese  fusion at reasonable prices!)

This rating is for the bar only, as we only had drinks. But they were the best cocktails we've had in a long time - truly wonderful flavor blends, without being "over the top". Oh, and the service was outstanding. Ask for Edith - she is terrific!

Excellent food and service.  We sat out on the square, and it was a great atmosphere.  I had the Gemelli with sausage and broccoli rabe, it was excellent.  The Gnocco appetizer was super tasty as well.  Our server was knowledgeable about the menu and offered wine pairings as well.  We really enjoyed our meal here.

Mario, you need to get back there and fix it. Unacceptable! Portion sizes are meager for the price, the table settings are bland and boring, not even a placemat? Come on! The broccoli rabe was inedible. I had to send it back, and I rarely send back food. Anyone who knows how to cook this vegetable knows that this time of year is the end of the season and the stems are tougher and need to be sliced or chopped and cooked separately to soften them up before adding the leaves.  None of my party of 5 had anything positive to say about the food. The meatballs in my colleagues meatballs were literally the size of meatballs you put on as a pizza topping. He couldn't stop talking about how small they were. Laughable if it wasn't for the price we paid.  I'm normally more cordial and constructive in my comments but this meal was offensive. I'd give it one star but the hostesses, servers and manager were both nice and professional.  Your empire is only as good as its foundation, which is the quality of your food, the value of the experience and the customers willing to pay for it. Forget that at your peril.

I've been here a couple of times.  They serve pretty good pizza here, the crust was fairly thin but had a good layer of cheese on it.    I've also had several of the verdure (vegetable) sides and think they are done very well (except kind of oily).  You can get three verdure as a dish, which is a good option for vegetarians and is reasonably priced and filling.  Love the "outdoor" seating area.

It's Vegas and service may not be as in a fine dining establishment. Randall was great but he wasn't our waiter, he was attentive, cleaned the table etc. The food is our major problem. We frequent mozza and we expected something similar. But Mario you have to come to Vegas and redo this restaurant. The pizza dough is terrible, if it can't be like mozza because of nancy silverton then maybe make it more like ny dough. The ingredients were good but the dough was awful,heavy,dense and awful taste. The main course was nothing great probably better at Olive Garden. We love Mario and we're very disappointed in our visit to Otto in Las Vegas

We were wandering around for a casual dinner, and this restaurant seem to offer the most enticing description on the menu, so we decided to give a go.    The lamb ragu, not too spicy made with homemade pasta and their lasagna was delicious down to the last bite.  The service was spot on and I'm so glad we settled here, because it would have been a crying shame to have bad Italian food.  They kept us busy with packaged bread sticks shipped from Italy and that was a fun conversational food item, while reminiscing about Rome.    It was $50 for two main courses and I'm glad they still serve after 10p.m. because I needed a nice hearty meal.  The portions are not massive, but they are filling.

Respect goes out to Mario for this joint.   I then proceed with my review. Hubby and I got dressed up in our wedding gear. After the gondola rides near by. We were hungry for some lunch. We stumbled onto this place prices seemed right.   Everyone was staring at us because I'm in my wedding dress. My Hubby was suited up. We sat at a table. Service got started immediately. We looked at the menus placed our order.   The manager was there saw us. And give us free liquor on the house because of the occasion. This was very classy of them to do this.  Hubby ordered pizza and I ordered ravioli's. I have to say it was the bomb. The portions were right for lunch time. Hubby couldn't finish his pizza lol. So he had to take the leftovers back to the resort we stayed at.    Pizza and raviolis yes please

To be honest, this was our last choice for food, but it ended up being a pretty solid choice. Our bachelor party of 12 dudes needed a casual spot to get food without spending too much (in the realm of Strip restaurants), and without traveling too far. Otto Enoteca fulfilled all of those needs quite well. Located by the shops in the Venetian, the space is surprisingly small for how big it looks from the outside, but we were able to get seated right away without a reservation, and drinks/water were distributed very quickly.  We all split some arancini (fried rice balls), which were quite excellent, so much so, that we ended up getting more orders of it to start off. As for my entree, I got the carbonara pizza, which had egg, scallion and guanciale on top, and was quite excellent. I assumed that the egg would just be a runny yolk on top, but it was actually scrambled on top, which turned out really well. The scallion had just enough bite to cut through the richness of the pizza, and I finished the pizza off quite quickly, almost wanting some more.   Service was pretty helpful and attentive, as much as can be in the late afternoon for a group of 12 hungry dudes. Prices were pretty much on par for a casual sit-down for the Strip, with pizzas around $20, and cocktails/wine were about $11-12.  Given the names behind this place (Batali and Bastianich), it's a pretty decent place for Italian if you're staying in the Venetian, but perhaps nothing to go out of your way for. Yet, if you need flexibility and have a large party for lunch or a casual dinner, Otto Enoteca will do quite nicely.
During peak meal times, there can be a wait for a table. Go for the bar instead and enjoy fast service. Order a cheese platter and wine for a shopping break and people watching.

The idea of eating inside the mall doesn't appeal to me but the food at Otto is always so satisfying that I go back again and again.  The pizzas are thin and crispy. They're good to have one for the table and share along with the pastas. The pasta portions are smaller than an average restaurant but great with the pizza. Mario Battali's bucatini all'Amatriciana is a must try.

We tried this place a year ago and loved it so much that it was the only place we knew we HAD to go to again when we were in Vegas just before Thanksgiving. This lovely little spot in the Venetian is wonderful. We got at table "outside" (which is really inside the Venetian) and Marissa, our waitperson, couldn't have been more engaging and knowledgeable and Daniel was very attentive. We ordered a small selection of cheeses to start off. The cheeses (parmesan, ricotta and taleggio) were a wonderful way to start along with the bread and oil/balsamic they bring out. The five of us all ordered pasta - a different selection  for each person but we passed around bites so we all got to try everything. One plate came out later than the others so the manager brought out a small dish to try until the entree came out (without asking or prompting - this is what a top quality restaurant does). It was made of pumpkin and farro with a smoked cheese - it was quite good. For my entree, I had the short-rib ravioli that was flavorful and simply done - exactly what I wanted. My daughter got the penne alla Norma which was my second choice as I love both eggplant and good ricotta. This was delicious too. Not one speck of food remained on any plate at the end of the meal and we even split a decadent dessert five ways - a honey semifreddo with poached pears. This is my favorite place to eat in Vegas. The service is top notch and the food is amazing.

Food was great and service!  But we were celebrating a birthday and instead of just bringing a desert and say happy birthday they asked us what dessert we would like as if it was more important to charge us which didn't matter but common sense just bring it and charge after!

The Pizza and Cannoli were outstanding! Both were so fresh and delicious! I only have two recommendations, one is for them to start serving mochas and second is to change the music. They were playing loud rock music at noon. It didn't match up with the ambiance of the restaurant at all. We had a hard time hearing one other and it would have been nice to hear something more appropriate for such a delicious noon time lunch.

Mediocre Italian Food. The wife and I were looking for somewhere to eat and stumbled upon this place. We thought that because it was one of Mario Batali's restaurants that the food must be excellent. My wife ordered the meatballs and I ordered the sausage and peppers pizza. We both found the food underwhelming and quite frankly not worth what they are charging. If only we had known there was a Carmine's across the street, we would have gone there instead. 4/10 would not recommend.

I was pretty skeptical about the menu at first, since all the item descriptions were pretty plain. Everything turned out to be really flavorful and delicious, though!  The truffle pizza is really potato-y with just the right amount of truffle that didn't overpower all the flavor. We also had the braised pork shoulder which was really tender and well-seasoned. The cucumber on top was a really nice contrast in texture and gave it a refreshing bite.   Being serenaded by the live music on the canal was nice, despite the loud gaggles of Asian tourists snapping photos with their iPads.   This was almost a 4-star review, but I am docking a star for the following reason:  The bill came out while my boyfriend was in the bathroom, so I put my card in and paid. When the check came back out for us to sign, the manager / host (he was checking people in but was also checking on the tables, so I assume he was some kind of manager) handed it to my boyfriend and said, "Thank you, Stephen." It may have been an innocent mistake, but it definitely came off as misogyny. It's the 21st century - women are allowed to pick up the tab once in a while. Poor form!

We had Arancini and the octopus salad. The Arancini - waaay too cheesy, but still lacked salt! The octopus salad was good.  I ordered the Pasta Norma, it was just ok. Really did not like the texture of the ricotta used in this dish.  Hubby ordered the spaghetti and meatballs, he enjoyed it.  Overall - too expensive for what you get. There are way too many restaurants to try for me to ever give this another chance.

I had dinner here and enjoyed some of their simple but scrumptious menu.   Started off with the mushroom bruschetta- the mushrooms were tasty even if the bread was slightly on the too crunchy side. It was topped by a light cheese (I'm sorry I don't know exactly what kind cheese it was but it tasted like provolone) and some chives to cut the richness of the dish.   For my main, I ordered the chicken paillard. The dish had many layers, starting with a slice of fried eggplant for crunch and bitterness. On it, they spread ricotta to add a creamy texture to the dish. They then added a layer of tomatoes followed by two layers of grilled chicken. The charred edges of the chicken added the perfect amount of smokiness to offset the ricotta. For a little bite and a little acid, they placed arugula that was dressed in a vinaigrette.  A little olive oil finished the dish.  It's a beautiful dish and worth a try.   For dessert, I had a pumpkin cheesecake. It's an interesting dish, composed of both crispy pumpkin chips (tastes similar to sweet potato chips) and thicker slices either boiled or grilled. Underneath was mascarpone (the cheese in the "cheesecake") nuts and graham cracker to mimic the flavours of a cheesecake. It was an interesting dessert but definitely not a sweet finish. If you want something sweet, then go for something else, like the gelato that they make in-house.   The only not so nice thing is the lighting - it's a bit too dark for my taste.   Tip: Daily specials are great - check the back of the menu.  Tip: If you're the designated driver of the night, ask about their sodas; they also make them fresh in-house.
